Australia is also involved in a number of organisations in the region, such as APEC, and we are very committed to advancing the cause of open and free trade in the Asia-Pacific region. Recently the foreign minister signed a free trade agreement in Singapore, and there are great possibilities of doing that with Thailand.

I want to say in the parliament that, for my part, it is important that I let the people of Ryan know of the contribution that I am making in small ways to promote the very critical relationship that this country has with Asia. In my maiden speech, I referred to the fact that I was the first Australian in the House of Representatives to have a Chinese heritage—a great source of pride to me. In the Ryan electorate I have had the opportunity of addressing both schoolchildren and teachers of language courses. In 2002 I had the great privilege of speaking at the National Chinese Teachers Conference at my old school of St Peter's Lutheran College at Indooroopilly, and only in June this year I had the privilege of speaking to the students of Centenary State High School. I was very kindly invited by Mrs Hu Richards to speak of my experience of studying a foreign language and of the wonderful opportunities that having another language can open up to individuals. In terms of the parliament, I have just had the great privilege of being in Cambodia, where I was with my colleague the member for Cowper. We had the opportunity of playing a part in the Cambodian national elections. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I say at the outset that, while we are all comforted that the member for La Trobe goes to copious meals with the Chinese leadership both here and in China, that probably has much to do with this government's determination to discuss human rights behind closed doors rather than in open dialogue. There is also their conduct towards Burma; in the Western world they are a pariah for their facilitation of that government through the so-called legal aides course. But I do welcome, although I am somewhat surprised by, the initiative of the member for Boothby in moving this motion. As the member for Burke detailed, it obviously again brings to light debates over migration and multiculturalism and, more particularly, those initiatives by the current Prime Minister which have unfortunately led to his current minister for immigration being forced to cross the floor of this parliament. So it does highlight that history, for all the talk about what the Liberal and conservative governments did after the Second World War, initiatives which were largely unavoidable in the context of the decline of colonialism anyway. They were really not earth-shattering initiatives. The opening of relationships with China was perhaps an initiative of some international importance—one undertaken by a Labor government.

speech.para: It also highlights the government's termination of the National Asian Languages and Studies in Australian Schools, NALSAS, strategy. All speakers on both sides have emphasised the need for Asian studies in this country. The decision to pull out of that funding initiative because it was supposedly self-sustaining is not really the highlight of activity on this front. Over $200 million was poured into it during that time. Despite the fact that half of our trade is with Asia, that we have significant Asian migration—we have had a fivefold increase since 1981, manifestly in Western Sydney and other regions—that there are a number of international hot spots, including the Korean Peninsular, Russian and Japanese border issues, Kashmir and its impact with regard to Islamic fundamentalism, and the Philippines and Mindanao autonomy moves and the Muslim insurgency there—despite all these positives as to why we should emphasise this area, the Asian Studies Association of Australia report Maximising Australia's Asia knowledge: repositioning and renewal of a national asset is fairly dire in its predictions. It notes:

quote.para: The momentum for the study of Asia which built up in the late 1980s and early 1990s is at risk ... we also identify an overall sense of diminution of resources, opportunities and expertise. Other inquiries of the 1990s point in similar directions. The key point is that the spread of useful knowledge of Asia among Australian university students is stalled.

speech.para: Earlier speakers detailed that the question of cost cutting and lack of taxpayer support for universities has led to a position where these courses have been downgraded and reduced, to the disappearance of some of our academics overseas and to a message to those people interested in this study area that your future may not be very rosy within Australia in these fields. Perhaps of course that is interrelated with the enhanced dominance of English internationally. Probably the mind-set of many Australians is that, with computerisation, international advertising and American media power, English has become so dominant that perhaps there is less value to Asian studies. However, I join with other speakers in saying that, if we are to understand the region, if we are to be a part of it, if we are to have advantages with regard to our crucial trade—as I said, essentially half of where we are seeking to operate is in Asia—then we should have an emphasis on this. The government's decision to end that funding is not in line with the spirit of the member's motion.

talk.start.para: (Mr Jenkins)—Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting. The honourable member for Reid will have leave to continue speaking when the debate is resumed.
—I move:

speech.para: That this House:
(1) acknowledges that 2003 marks the celebration of 100 years of piloted flight;

(2) notes the Wright Brothers' achievement in success-fully undertaking the first flight as the culmination of a centuries' old quest by philosophers, scientists and engineers to turn the dream of flight into a reality that re-defined the boundaries of scientific capacity;
(3) notes that, in the 100 years since the first piloted flight, the outstanding development in air travel has taken us from the Wright Brothers' Kitty Hawk flight to the Moon;

(4) recognises that the invention, growth and refinement of piloted flight has allowed us to cross and expand our boundaries, both personal, cultural, economic and national, enriching our experiences and bringing people of the world closer together;
(5) notes that the aviation industry has also fostered inter and intra State and Territory trade, commerce and experiences;
(6) recognises the importance of the aviation industry to Australian jobs, skills and indus-try, in particular, to the tourism, aeronautical, technical, engineering, and ex-port industries;
(7) acknowledges the aviation industry as an important provider of high skilled jobs to Australians;
(8) notes with disappointment the collapse of Ansett Airlines and recognises the valuable role that Ansett played in the development of the aviation industry in Australia;
(9) notes proudly that Qantas is an Australian icon, recog-nised throughout the world and one of Australia's largest private sector employers;
(10) welcomes the newer players in Australia like Virginblue and Regional Express and recognises the import-ant contribution of regional airlines and operators to our regional communities;
(11) acknowledges the work, enterprise, inn-ovation, ingenuity, commitment, passion and enthusiasm of all those who have worked in aviation over the past one hundred years;
(12) pays its respects to all those who have died in the pursuit of work and recreation in aviation;
(13) notes the negative effect of the terrorist attacks of September 11 on the global aviation and associated in-dustries and expresses our hope that the industry will recover;

(14) notes the vital need for Federal Government efforts to ensure that airline passengers can travel in the safest possible environment, in particular now Australia is a terrorist target, to restore confidence in air travel; and
(15) notes the importance of a competitive and sustainable local aviation industry.

It is a delight and a privilege to have the opportunity to address the House this afternoon in celebration of 100 years of piloted flight—a remarkable milestone that must be recognised for its significant impact on the development of society. Piloted flight gave us the ability to bring communities closer together as the tyranny of distance was overcome. In changing the face of long-distance travel, piloted flight also gave us the ability to expand our horizons by taking Australians to the world and the world to Australia.

Piloted flight has given us the opportunity to enrich our cultural and personal lives, as well as to expand economic and national interests. Aviation has also played a very significant role in our armed forces. It should also be acknowledged that piloted flight has been a key factor in the development of our local economies by forging closer and stronger ties between intrastate and interstate activities. Australia has played a key role in the development of the aviation industry, and today it is one of the nation's largest private sector employers. Aviation now provides the backbone to many local industries, from tourism to engineering, and is backed by a highly skilled work force.

The story of flight goes hand in hand not only with the story of a fabulous new industry in Australia but also with the growth of Australia as a nation. Qantas and Ansett are both indelibly etched into not only Australia's history but also the history of global aviation. Virgin Blue, a new player, is now carving out its own place in the domestic aviation industry, as are Regional Express and many other regional aviation companies. The industry is working hard in regaining and maintaining a competitive and vibrant airline industry following the significant downturn experienced in the wake of the September 11 terrorist attacks, Iraq, the SARS crisis and the ongoing global terrorism alert. But we cannot assume that the industry is invincible.

The success of aviation is integrally linked to security, and this has been driven home in the past two years more than ever. I think it is fair to say that terrorism is the biggest threat to the future of the aviation industry ever contemplated in its 100 years. Politicians, academics and the media therefore have a responsibility to bear this in mind when commenting on security issues. All pressure must be put on the government and industry to ensure the safest possible travelling environment, but the issues should be raised in a responsible, constructive manner that does not blow risk out of proportion. We must be alert to the fact that not only terrorist acts but also self-serving, exaggerated threats can undo the proud history of achievement in aviation.

The Wright brothers back in 1903 embarked on a journey that changed the face of travel. In turn, that had a direct impact on the enrichment and expansion of communities through the easier ability to share experiences, cultures and ideas. How lucky Australia was as a result of that opportunity. The message today is that we as a nation—each and every one of us—should therefore not let terrorists, fearmongerers and self-servers jeopardise this achievement and opportunity. It is hard to fathom exactly what type of world we would live in had it not been for the enterprise, ingenuity, commitment, passion and enthusiasm of the Wright brothers to turn the dream of flight into a reality. It is therefore with great pleasure that I commend the motion to the House and in doing so place on record this House's recognition of 100 years of piloted flight—an international achievement and an achievement of major importance to Australia as a nation. It is a part of our cultural and economic development. We would not have been so strong without its input. I commend the motion to the House.

talk.start.para: (Mr Jenkins)—Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

—It should come as no surprise to honourable members that the history of aviation and the contribution of a particular individual are topics that are very close to my heart—after all, I am the member for Hinkler, a seat that bears the name of one of Australia's greatest solo aviators. In fact, the new seat of Hinkler was designated in 1983 and the name was suggested by a member of the Hinkler commemoration committee, Tom Quinn. Little did I think that, within 10 years, I would be representing that seat.

speech.para: While endorsing the sentiments of the member for Batman, I would like to expand on Bert Hinkler's contribution to solo aviation and aviation history. In 1911 and 1912 he flew a glider at Mon Repos beach near Bundaberg—an extraordinary effort for a 19-year-old—only eight years after the Wright brothers' historic flight. His greatest achievement was that he was the first person to fly solo from England to Australia. In 1928 this involved flying his Avro Avian 11,000 miles, from Croydon Airport to Darwin, in 15½ days. Amongst his other achievements was the first solo flight across the Atlantic from South America to the west coast of Africa.

That was preceded by a very colourful history. Bert Hinkler joined the Royal Naval Air Service in World War I as an observer and gunner and was awarded the Distinguished Service Medal for shooting down enemy planes. Again in keeping with the sentiment of the motion, I acknowledge his extraordinary contribution as chief test pilot for A.V. Roe and Co., known later as Avro and today as British Aerospace, where he tested the Avro series and the earliest gyrocopters, which were the forerunners of helicopters.

In 1921 he flew an Avro Baby from Sydney to Bundaberg—then a record distance for a solo flight. It was many years before this record was eclipsed. Following the famous 1928 flight he was feted like a modern-day astronaut, complete with a civic reception on the steps of the Old Parliament House. He went on to design an amphibious craft, known as the Ibis, before his untimely and tragic death on the Prato Magno Alps in Italy in 1933. Mussolini's Italian government accorded him the equivalent of a state funeral.

All of Hinkler's achievements are recorded in Hinkler House Memorial Museum in the Botanical Gardens of North Bundaberg. This house was brought from England, where it was under threat of demolition, to Australia in 1983. It was brought here brick by brick in two 20-tonne containers and re-erected following the original architect's plans, donated by the Southampton City Council, in whose environs the house was previously located. I take some pride in being one of the three people, along with Tom Quinn and the chair of the Hinkler House Memorial Museum and Research Association, Lex Rowland, who put this project together. We were ably assisted by East Bundaberg Rotary Club and in particular by builder Stan Lohse, engineer Bert Bent, Ray Townsend, Merv Purkis, John Wientjens and Bryce Palm.

Much like Captain Cook's cottage, the house was the stimulus for the creation of Bundaberg's magnificent botanical gardens, and it has attracted more than 400,000 visitors since it opened. The house overlooks the gardens, three lakes where Hinkler watched the ibis in flight as a boy and got his ideas on flight, and an historical tourist tramline. The south of the house overlooks the sporting grounds where Hinkler landed in triumph in 1928 and gained the adulation of the people of Bundaberg, an adulation which has not dimmed with the years. It is hoped to complete the Hinkler cycle by housing his five planes in a museum of national dimensions, to be known as the Hinkler Hall of Aviation. It will adjoin the house and make a key historical and tourist attraction. In fact, it will be an anchor attraction in the Bundaberg community.

talk.start.para: —On 17 December 1903, at a remote fishing village called Kitty Hawk in North Carolina, Orville Wright piloted the first controlled, sustained, piloted flight in a heavier-than-air craft. The fact that this first flight was assisted by a purpose-built monorail, with Wilbur Wright holding the wing, and that it lasted only 12 seconds and travelled about 37 metres, is irrelevant—the history of piloted flight was born on that day. Therefore, I have no hesitation in rising today to second this motion, celebrate the centenary of such flight and reflect upon the extraordinary impact this human invention has had upon the world.

speech.para: I think I am correct in saying that no other technological advance in the history of travel has so fundamentally transformed our capacity to gain access to parts of the world once only the domain of the very privileged, the very adventurous and, some might say, the very brave. Piloted flight, especially since the growth of commercial air travel, has made the world smaller for millions of people.

There is an Australian story or two within this marvellous chapter of human endeavour. We have just heard, from the member for Hinkler, about that seat's namesake and his efforts in the area of aviation. I add to that the efforts of Charles Kingsford Smith, or `Smithy', as he was known. He was known also as an Australian larrikin and as a fearless pilot who was first to fly across the Pacific. Perhaps `fearless' is not the right word, as I understand that he had an abiding fear of the water. But, clearly, he had the capacity and the courage to fight that phobia on his extraordinarily brave, long flights. Another pilot, Nancy Bird Walton—again, another Australian—was the first woman pilot in the Commonwealth to carry passengers. She was a student of Kingsford Smith's.

Of course, I think it is important to acknowledge both Qantas and Ansett. As Australia's chief carriers, these national icons contributed well to the aviation industry. Qantas has an extraordinary safety record. It is recognised around the world as a very good company. It flies our flag throughout the world. Alas, Ansett, that great institution, is no more. On a sadder note, I would like to acknowledge that the second anniversary of Ansett's demise is less than a week away. Only last week I met again with a few of the several thousand former Ansett workers that live in my electorate of Burke. As casualties of one of the largest corporate disasters in this nation's history they have asked me to ensure that they and their families are not forgotten. Of those who lost their jobs, few have found full-time permanent work and many have had to survive by taking casual and part-time jobs. Others have found no work at all.

I could provide this House with many stories of the losses endured by many former Ansett workers. There has been the loss of family homes, there has been loss of self-esteem and there has been the breakdown of many families. The former Ansett workers I met with want me to tell people generally—and I do so in this place—that, contrary to a growing perception amongst some, they have not been provided with their full entitlements and they have not received all of their redundancy or all of their superannuation. Indeed, they wait still for money they are owed. Their situation needs redressing, and I think it is fair to say that we must do more to protect Australian workers from such corporate collapses. Surely we can figure out a better way to protect our work force from such economic and social disasters. But this motion in its entirety is about hope, courage and ingenuity. It is about what we can do when we dare to dream and dare to live those dreams. So, as I said, I have no hesitation in seconding this motion. I commend the motion to the House.

talk.start.para: —I am delighted to also be able to support this motion, which celebrates 100 years of piloted flight. I want to particularly acknowledge the men and women who made it all happen and made it possible. They were so well recognised in that great movie about early space flight, The Right Stuff. They were pioneers of their age and without their extraordinary bravery we would not be where we are in aviation today.

speech.para: I would like to draw the attention of the House to a story about a great air race that involved the town of Albury in my electorate of Farrer. In 1934, a participant in the London to Melbourne Centenary Air Race became lost in severe thunderstorms on the final leg of the journey. Around midnight on 23 October, the Dutch Douglas airliner Uiver began circling Albury after losing its way. Communication was established with the Corowa radio station, 2CO, which broadcast an appeal to motorists, asking them to assemble at the Albury Racecourse to light the fields with their headlights. This they did, responding in true country fashion. In torrential rain and on a runway of 200 yards—not long for a DC2—the aircraft made a perfect landing. The next morning 300 spectators gathered to pull the aircraft out with ropes—by that time it was completely bogged. The pilots, called Parmentier and Moll, got rid of everything, including the mail and the passengers, and they took off once more, actually going on to win the handicap section of the great air race and to take second place overall. This was an important milestone for Australia. It actually proved something interesting, which was that Britain and Europe were closer than we thought—less than four days away! Three years later, in 1937, the airport at Albury was constructed.

Tocumwal is another important aerodrome in my electorate. It was a World War II air base. It now houses an aviation museum and is a very important gliding centre. International gliders gather there. The Wentworth Shire Council has come up with the innovative idea of a residential estate at another airport in that shire. That, of course, is a recreational pilot's dream come true.

Returning to the story of the great air race, I would like to acknowledge the activities of our Albury West Rotary Club, which actually undertook restoration of the airframe of an almost identical DC2 in the 1970s—the original Uivercrashed in a sandstorm in Libya a few months after the race, I understand. With permission from the Dutch government, the replica was painted with the Uiver's original markings and installed on pylons near Albury Airport. It was further restored during 2000, and it is undergoing further restoration today, in recognition of the important cultural position it holds in the history of Albury.

I also acknowledge the young men and women over the last 100 years who have dedicated themselves to the pursuit of careers in aviation, whether those careers involved flying in the left seats of jumbo jets, as I would have liked, or flying in small single-engine aeroplanes close to the ground, mustering sheep and cattle, as I actually did. I recall, as so many would, juggling three jobs after leaving school in order to fund the cost of my commercial licence. I remember standing on the tarmac at Canberra airport, breathing in the smell of aviation gasoline having just completed my first solo and thinking, `It doesn't get any better than this.' I have to acknowledge that I was a very slow learner. In fact, my instructor did say to me: `Sussan, are you sure this is really what you want to do? You may be better suited to other pursuits.' But I persisted, and that is, of course, what flying does to you. A career in aviation is pursued out of love and never out of a desire for financial reward. It becomes an obsession rather than something that you just do during business hours. The general aviation scene is traditionally full of dedicated pilots keen to add hours to their log books and fly for little return. It is this devotion and commitment that I believe actually helps keep Australia's skies safe.

I think it is fair to say that ordinary pilots are overwhelmed by some of the requirements imposed upon them by CASA, which admittedly does have to walk a fine line between policing the industry and assisting it. I just wish to pay tribute to those ordinary pilots in my electorate, all of whom I enjoy hearing from, who have expressed frustration with all the rules and regulations about airspace and maintenance that they have to deal with each time they want to make a simple flight in aircraft they have been flying for years.

I must pay tribute to women in aviation and to the Australian Women Pilots Association. We have heard mention of Nancy Bird Walton. Her family bought her first aircraft, a De Havilland Gipsy Moth, and Nancy and a friend set off on a tour, barnstorming and giving joy rides at country shows. We also have Gaby Kennard, who in 1989 became the first Australian woman to fly solo around the world, in her single-engine Piper Saratoga. I pay tribute to all these pioneers in Australia and internationally.

talk.start.para: —It gives me great pleasure to speak today in support of the member for Batman's motion dealing with the upcoming centenary of piloted flight and on the role that Australians have played in advancing the aviation industry both locally and abroad. As we all know, the development of piloted flight has changed the face of our planet by bringing diverse communities and cultures into much closer contact than our ancestors a century ago could ever have imagined. Aircraft save lives, and they enhance trade, migration and cultural exchange. Qantas is a good example of this.

speech.para: While we celebrate the achievements of Orville and Wilbur Wright at Kitty Hawk in North Carolina on 17 December 1903, when they accomplished the first powered flight in a heavier-than-air machine, it is fitting that we recall two key Australian breakthroughs leading up to that epic achievement. On 12 November 1894, Lawrence Hargrave, the Australian inventor of the box kite, linked four of his kites together and added a sling seat, and flew 16 feet at Stanwell Park, in the northern part of my electorate of Cunningham. That was almost a decade before the Wright brothers' achievement.

By demonstrating to a sceptical public that it was possible to build a safe and stable flying machine, Hargrave opened the door to other inventors and pioneers. The Hargrave designed box kite, with its improved lift-to-drag ratio, was to provide the theoretical wing model that allowed the development of the first generation of aeroplanes. The first successful aircraft incorporated three crucial aeronautical concepts developed by Hargrave: the cellular box kite wing, the curved wing surface and the thick leading wing edge—the aerofoil. Hargrave did not patent the groundbreaking results of his research, believing that whatever he could do to promote the development of flying machines would be reward enough. He regularly communicated with the Royal Society of New South Wales and, through that group, with the rest of the world.

The Wright brothers also had access to Hargrave's work, through the aviation annuals published by James Means, and through Octavius Chanute's Progress in Flying Machines, which included a section on Hargrave's experiments. The Wright brothers also corresponded with Chanute. However, the Wright brothers, constrained by the politics and patent problems of their time, admitted no influences.

Hargrave's influence on the evolution of flying is more discernible in Europe. The French freely acknowledged Hargrave's influence. In 1906, Alberto Santos-Dumont became the first European to fly a heavier-than-air machine, which was constructed of Hargrave box kites. When Gabriel Voisin built the first commercially available aircraft, based on the stable lifting surfaces of Hargrave's box kites, he called them `Hargraves'.

Hargrave's second great achievement was that in 1889 he revolutionised engine technology by inventing the radial rotary engine, which reappeared in 1908—unacknowledged and in a modified form—as the French `Gnome' engine. Although as early as 1892 Hargrave had voiced his opposition to the idea of the `connection of the flying machine with dynamite missiles', the rotating radial engine was extensively used in military aircraft until it was superseded many years later by new engine technologies.

Hargrave's concern for the peaceful promulgation of knowledge was evidenced in his concern for the safe placement of his working models in an environment open to the public. The only museum that would meet his terms was the Deutsches Technological Museum in Munich. It is therefore ironic that most of Hargrave's 176 working models were destroyed in the Allied aerial bombardment of Germany during World War II. The 25 surviving models were restored to Sydney's Powerhouse Museum in the 1960s.

Lawrence Hargrave's face once graced our $20 note, and a memorial to him has been built at Stanwell Park. I must pay tribute to the work of the Lawrence Hargrave Foundation, which is chaired by one of my constituents, Mr Eric Waite of Thirroul. The foundation is keeping Hargrave's memory alive with activities including annual kite flying days, which involve students from local schools. These take place at the very same beach at Stanwell Park—and on the anniversary of the day—on which this great Australian pioneer of aviation first became airborne. The house in which he lived still stands adjacent to the beautiful coast road, which is named Lawrence Hargrave Drive in his honour. That road, however, has been closed since early July, effectively cutting the northern part of my electorate in two.

Hargrave's 1902 design was put to the test in 1992 when students at the University of Sydney rebuilt his aircraft from the original blueprint, replacing Hargrave's power plant with a modern one—and it flew. Hargrave's memory could best be served if the road named after him were reopened as soon as possible, thus ensuring that tribute to Lawrence Hargrave, Australia's father of flight, is restored to the people of Cunningham. I therefore commend the motion to the House.

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to be speaking on this motion relating to aviation today, particularly when I represent an electorate that has one of the biggest regional airports in Australia, at Williamtown. I think we can all marvel at the amazing feats of Wilbur and Orville Wright who, in December 1903, through sheer hard work, courage and vision, piloted the first successful powered flights in a heavier-than-air machine. The first flight may have lasted only 12 seconds and gone 120 feet on that day in North Carolina, but at the beginning of a new century it was a feat that really captured the imagination of people around the world.

speech.para: The rapid pace of technological change has meant that air travel has touched every pocket of the world and has even led to space travel. And who knows where air travel will take us in the next 100 years? When will the day come when civilians, not just astronauts, will be landing on the moon? This kind of imagination led to the Wright brothers' success and has paved the way for extraordinary feats in aviation over the last 100 years.

The development of aviation has been enormously important for regional areas in Australia. Take the Newcastle airport for example. Not only does this airport service the Hunter region by providing a link to major cities; it also provides a boon for high-skilled jobs in the area. The airport leases space from, and shares a runway with, the RAAF base at Williamtown, which is one of the biggest employers in the entire Hunter region. As a result, the area does attract a high level of defence related industries.

This year, Newcastle airport has made some announcements that are likely to bring even more skilled jobs to the region. The first was back in May, when it was announced that the Australian International Aerospace Centre would be developed at Newcastle airport. The centre will comprise offices, workshops and aircraft facilities that will support defence and commercial operators with a number of uses. Tenants for the 26-hectare site have been identified already. With the RAAF Williamtown base nearby, it is expected that the centre will attract more defence related companies to the region and become a national centre of aviation excellence in what is described as an $80 million redevelopment over the next 10 years.

One company that is relocating to Williamtown is FlightStat Data-Link. They plan to manufacture and test crash survival memory units for the RAAF base. FlightStat is a small innovation and technology development company that engineers and designs products for the aerospace and aviation industry. The project is expected to create around 20 jobs in the area.

Construction has already started on a $149 million redevelopment at the RAAF base, which will be the new headquarters for the RAAF No. 2 Squadron and the airborne early warning and control aircraft. Over the life of the redevelopment, there will be 350 permanent positions at Williamtown, which will be for a combination of military personnel, public servants and contractors. The construction of the headquarters will create around 200 direct jobs on the base and more jobs indirectly in the building industry throughout my community.

So the aviation industry is looking positive in the Hunter, with more jobs on the way through the RAAF and through the further development of Newcastle airport. Given the enormous impact that terrorism and SARS have had on the industry, it is pleasing to see a regional market looking positively to the future. These two issues are something that the federal government has taken very seriously. Just last month, the Deputy Prime Minister, John Anderson, announced that Australia's aviation security framework would be assessed as part of the continuous review process. The assessment is about making sure we are actively managing our security at our airports and it will look at intelligence, transport, border control and security experts.

It is another example of how this government is strengthening aviation security, and it joins other measures that the government has taken, including upgraded counter-terrorism first response capability, arrangements for screening all checked baggage, stricter security arrangements for international and domestic cargo, expanded explosive detection capability, air security officers on domestic flights and tighter airport access control.

The staff at our airports and in the aviation industry should be congratulated on their efforts to implement these measures designed to provide safer travelling for our public. I look forward to when all of these measures will be implemented at Newcastle airport—an airport that, as I said, is one of the largest employers in my electorate, through the RAAF and Newcastle Airport Ltd. Newcastle airport has international capabilities which are underutilised at the moment and we look forward to further expansion. I wholly commend this motion to the House.

talk.start.para: (Mr Jenkins)—Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.

—I wish to raise concerns about the future of the Landcare movement. I am pleased to see the Minister for the Environment and Heritage and the parliamentary secretary in the House. We are at a time when severe crises in Australia's environment demand urgent action. The results of decades of unsustainable land use and vast clearing of native vegetation and habitat do not exist in some mythical future but are happening now.

speech.para: On current trends the total area of—mainly farming—land affected by salinity in Australia is expected to rise to over 15½ million hectares. This is an increase of over 620 per cent from the current unacceptable 2½ million hectares and it does not include the consequences of the hitherto unchecked land clearing in Queensland. Within 20 years, drinking water supplies taken from the Murray River in South Australia will, on average, be too salty to drink two days out of every five. On current salinity trends, internationally significant Ramsar listed wetlands such as New South Wales's Macquarie Marshes will become wastelands within this lifetime. The water agreement struck recently is a very welcome milestone, but the journey has only just begun.

In April this year the Australian Terrestrial Biodiversity Assessment gave a stark picture of the collapse of Australia's rich biodiversity. Australia already accounts for a third of the world's recent mammal extinctions, with 22 mammals already gone and another eight just hanging on but only on the islands. Another 346 animals and birds, eight invertebrates and an incredible 1,241 plants are facing a threatened survival. With Australia containing about 10 per cent of the world's biodiversity, this is nothing short of environmental disaster. Even our previously thought pristine wilderness areas are facing the same sort of biodiversity loss, and nearly 3,000 unique bushland types throughout Australia are at risk of disappearing—from the Kimberley to Northern Australia to the Queensland rainforests.

One of the worst droughts in living memory—with Australians in rural areas still struggling with the consequences—and the crisis of the once mighty Murray have refocused attention on the Australian continent's fragile and dying ecosystems. We have a once unlikely coalition of conservationists and farmers agreeing that this ravaged country needs urgent restoration. Their 2000 manifesto, Repairing the country,put a $60 billion figure on the cost of repairing land clearing, salinity and soil degradation, with a minimum cost of $4½ billion needed immediately. That is four times the amount of money already delivered by the government's Natural Heritage Trust, which—welcome though it is—unfortunately had to be funded by the part sale of Telstra. The Prime Minister's Science, Engineering and Innovation Council has costed the repair bill at $6 billion per year.

This is the current picture. Yet bleak as it is there is another, brighter story being told, where land-holders and regional communities have been identifying environmental problems in their own paddocks and putting together projects to address them. That is the Landcare movement. From its small beginnings in the mid-1980s, Landcare has nourished solid partnerships between farmers and environmentalists, scientists, land managers and different levels of government. It has grown to over 4,250 groups across Australia. Between 30 and 40 per cent of Australia's primary land managers—our farmers—are members of a Landcare group, with many of the remainder accessing those extension services hitherto provided by government and seeking individual support to achieve environmentally sustainable management practices on their land.

The Landcare movement embodies an investment of 15 years of community and individual commitment—15 years of capacity building and education, of turning around entrenched attitudes, and of ownership of local environmental problems and their solutions. It is people coming together to improve our environment for the public good. Landcare is Australia's own unique success story and it has been copied worldwide. But now it is itself in need of support. With diminishing funding dollars and our environmental values being eroded and felled at an unsustainable rate, it is obvious that a more integrated approach to natural resource management is urgently needed. It makes sense to better coordinate community and government efforts within a catchment by allocating resources towards those issues determined as priorities and fitting in within an overall plan—the catchment blueprint.

But, in moving towards a regional model of natural resource management, there is a grave danger of moving away from local ownership of projects and losing the enormous asset of the grassroots goodwill and social capital so vital to the success of so many environmental solutions. It is essential that the funds and energy put into regional priorities are matched by strong links with community. Those regional bodies overseeing the catchment blueprints must recognise and support land care and community. If those linkages are not built into the new framework and local ownership of projects is diminished with the new regional model of environmental funding, the momentum built over the past 15 years will diminish and the dollars poured into projects could well turn out to be a complete waste of money.

Over the past year, the concerns I have heard from Landcare groups are numerous and worrying. The catchment management boards, faced with a huge job of change management within impossibly short time frames, are unsure of their own futures beyond the end of the year and have been part of the general uncertainty that is undermining Landcare confidence. The new authority model—although it is generally thought that it will provide much-needed accountability and transparency—has yet to be established, and that means more change. Information about strategies for investment, informing the community and the prospective community service officer positions has yet to be released. Despite this lack of guidelines, committed people are being invited to apply for the positions, which are to be filled by next month.

Community groups face losing their expert guidance and their major link with the whole process—their Landcare coordinators. They face an uncertain future, with the real possibility that their own management plans may not even get a look in under the regional priorities. In my electorate, community groups have not been privy to information that has informed and involved their own priorities. Already I hear of groups wanting to give up because they believe their voice is no longer deemed important enough. Without the coordinators and the facilitators from those groups to encourage, educate and involve, we run a huge risk of leaving behind the input of the farmer, or the new blockie, leaving them withering on the branch. This important change in our natural resource management funding has been handled abysmally and is causing great damage at a grassroots level. Perhaps the government knows better and we are not being told, but it seems to me that the state government has a large role to play in this, and this has contributed enormously to the uncertainty.

While the new regional authority model is mooted to be more accountable, there need to be mechanisms embedded to ensure a transparent community-led regional assessment that actively involves land managers and responds to subcatchment priorities. There needs to be an assurance built into the framework that NHT2 funds will not be absorbed by research that has already been done, by government coffers—in the states particularly—and by the rapidly growing private consultancy industry. The money must reach the ground where it is so urgently needed. The new authorities must include in their constitutions a demand for capacity building and true community involvement. At the end of the day it is the landowners, and their community support, who can and do commit to and deliver the specific outcomes. Accredited property management plans must also be allowed every opportunity to link into the regional plan. This further empowers the landowner and allows the mapping of progress and an accountable means of delivering public money. In Victoria, the BushTender pilot program has received terrific support from landholders, and maybe that is the sort of model that is needed.

All of this is obvious, but the change does not seem to be taking these issues into account. It seems to be ad hoc, at least in the minds of the Landcare people I speak to. Our Landcare groups and our long-suffering catchment management boards are waiting, with bated breath, for the next instalment. To their credit, the New South Wales Minister for Natural Resources and our own federal ministers are hearing these concerns and, I believe, are responding. There are people on the tablelands who are anxious to get on with the job now that they have had three inches of rain; in fact, they are going to self-fund their coordinator position in the intervening period, so concerned are they that the continuity must be there.

We need to make sure that, when this drought breaks, the community and the land-holder will be there to provide the most important part of this jigsaw; and it is like a big jigsaw. It is no good looking at the completed model; we have got to look at the constituent bits. These people are telling me that their concern is that their own efforts will be disregarded—and that is something to which a dollar value just cannot be put.

talk.start.para: —Prior to and immediately after my election into this place, two significant road safety issues were raised by the community with the former member for Hume—former transport minister the Hon. John Sharp—and me. These two issues were the Barton Highway Murrumbateman bypass and the Towrang Road and Carrick Road intersections with the Hume Highway north of Goulburn. Both of these sites have failed to attract funding from the federal government, despite each of them being identified as a danger to motorists.

speech.para: The Murrumbateman bypass has been the subject of a considerable amount of criticism from members of the community, who were concerned about the long delay in the announcement of an eastern or western bypass route. The community had a justifiable reason for being concerned about the time it was taking to identify the preferred bypass route. It would not be unreasonable to suggest that much of the delay at that time had been influenced by the considerable political pressure being exerted by a developer who would benefit from a bypass route to the west of Murrumbateman. Nevertheless, after eight studies and reports, hundreds of thousands of dollars of taxpayers funds and reams of correspondence—the majority of which favoured the eastern option as the preferred route—the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Transport and Regional Services, the Hon. John Anderson, made an announcement in favour of the eastern route, on 5 October 2001 in a press release. Minister Anderson also indicated in that press release that `the Murrumbateman bypass did not have sufficient priority for construction to proceed in the foreseeable future'. He also said:

quote.para: Before construction is able to commence, a full environmental impact statement will need to be prepared and this will involve further community consultation about the design elements of a bypass along an eastern alignment.

speech.para: A number of deaths and serious injuries as recently as March and July this year—two people were killed and 12 injured—have occurred since that time on the Barton Highway near Murrumbateman and yet no further announcement has been forthcoming of an EIS or that funding has been allocated to commence the bypass project.

This in an environment in which millions of dollars have been allocated to projects with far less urgency—if any—in regard to road safety reasons and which are certainly lower down the scale of traffic volumes and crash statistics. This is not the first time I have raised these issues in this place. As recently as 17 June of this year I rose in this place in the adjournment debate and talked about these issues and I tried to stress the urgency of the need for something to be done in these particular accident spots.
I also would like to refer to a couple of press reports regarding the most recent accidents I talked about. From the Yass Tribune:

quote.para: Twelve people were injured in an accident on the Barton Highway near Murrumbateman ...
The accident occurred at 10.30am, when the driver of a Commodore station wagon lost control of her vehicle on the sweeping bend at the end of the 60 kilometre zone.
The vehicle collided with an oncoming Ford Fairmont sedan.

The Commodore driver, a 36 year old Yass woman, her passenger a 33 year old Canberra woman and five children aged between two and fourteen years were all conveyed to Canberra Hospital for treatment of injuries sustained in the accident. The adult passenger was trapped for almost an hour before being freed by rescue crews.
Also conveyed to Canberra hospital was the driver of the Ford, a 36 year old ACT man, his 24 year old female passenger and three children aged between three and eight years.

The accident occurred in the same spot in which a Canberra woman died on March 29 after her car collided with a bus. These accidents have sparked calls for funding to be made available for construction of the Murrumbateman Bypass.

speech.para: The article went on to say that this in an environment in which the:

quote.para: ... 1999-2000 budget said planning for a $14.5 million bypass was underway, but construction would not commence until 2005.

speech.para: The mayor at that time, Mayor Nic Carmody:

quote.para: ... called on the Federal Government to address the need to upgrade the route, which is a high traffic route for Canberra commuters.

speech.para: Following on from that in a more recent article in the Yass Tribune:

quote.para: A Murrumbateman man was killed in an accident on the Barton Highway ...
The accident occurred at midnight, when the 37-year-old man lost control of his vehicle north of Casuarina Lane.
The vehicle left the roadway and the driver was ejected from the vehicle, sustaining serious injuries.
Police and ACT ambulance officers attended the scene, conveying the driver to Canberra Hospital, where he died a few hours later.

speech.para: It is not just an issue of that particular section of road, as I said at the outset. There are another two very serious intersections where I believe if we do not act very quickly we are going to have some very serious accidents. I refer to the Towrang Road and Carrick Road intersections on the Hume Highway, which are also being subjected to what I can only describe as deliberate obfuscating and delaying procedures in the way of reports and public talkfests, similar to the Murrumbateman bypass saga—the most recent example being last month's public consultation, followed by a graphic display of the three options at the Towrang Community Hall on Saturday 9 August 2003.

To date there has been no commitment to the timing of the project from the RTA or to the funding of the project, which—it is estimated—will cost between $3 million and $10 million, depending on which of the three options is decided on. My enquiries have revealed that the project is at least four years away from commencement. In other words, as for the Murrumbateman bypass, there is no urgency attached to this project despite the potential for a serious accident causing multiple deaths and injuries.

If it is simply a matter of funds, one has to question the appropriateness of the way in which funds are being allocated from the budget. Are funds being distributed on the basis of priority, fairly and equitably and with regard to road safety? I say that in the context of the lead-up to the state election this year, during which my parliamentary colleague the National Party member for Burrinjuck, Katrina Hodgkinson, in response to a question from the Goulburn Post on 7 March on page 6 had this to say:

quote.para: “It is a Federal issue.
The thing that really irks me about road funding is it's based on fatalities. Does there need to be blood shed before something is done?
Visibility coming out of Towrang Rd is very limited. That visibility needs to be greatly improved for a start.”

speech.para: I also refer to a comment on 5 March on page 3 of the same paper, the Goulburn Post:

quote.para: Greenwich Park residents, Lillian Pain and her husband Nick are so concerned about road safety at the Towrang Rd intersection with the Hume Highway, they will not allow their child, Aaron (6) to travel to school at State Joseph's on the daily school bus.

speech.para: That is just a small indication of the sorts of problems there are with regard to that particular section of road.

If there are not sufficient funds available now, why cannot the funds needed to complete these two outstanding road safety projects be sourced from the reserves held under the Australian Land Transport Development Act 1988? I say that because I became aware of that particular act about three or four months ago. I was able to get some information on it. It would appear that in some sections of that particular act there is ample scope for the minister of the day to use some of those funds to fix that intersection. I might add that in that particular reserve at the moment there is $1.025 billion currently available for just that purpose. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I welcome the opportunity to speak in this grievance debate. Mr Deputy Speaker Causley, you would be aware that for some time now I have been interested in family law matters. One of my particular areas of interest is section 121 of the Family Law Act, which was introduced in 1983. Originally, when the act was changed in 1975, there was a total prohibition on the publication of any information on actions before the Family Court. In 1983, following a joint select committee's recommendation that there ought to be some publicity about the Family Court, section 121 was introduced. It was introduced, I might stress, to provide publicity, not prohibit it. One of the key aspects of section 121 was that there should be no identification of the parties appearing before the Family Court.

speech.para: I think it is fair to say that the effect of section 121 has not met the expectations of that particular committee. A subsequent joint committee recommended in 1992 that the Family Court make the media aware of the provisions of section 121 and encourage further reporting of the proceedings of the court. Whether or not the court has done that, the effect has been the same—that is, there has been no real publicity of matters before the Family Court. The one exception of course has been the development of the Internet, as there is some freedom on the Internet in relation to family law matters.

What I have done is to develop a family law amendment bill. It is not my intention here to give notice to move that amendment bill but rather to put on the public record what I suggest is a useful way to change section 121. I have called for a repealing of section 121, replacing the powers in that section by giving discretion to the court to develop court rules which would allow publicity of cases. In any other court apart from the Children's Court, parties before a court can apply to the judge for suppression orders, which are decided on two things: court rules and the merits of the application. Under my proposed family law amendment bill, parties could approach the judge for a suppression order; alternatively, the judge on his own motion would be able to initiate a suppression order.

As a member—a very new one—of the Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs and given its responsibility to look at family law matters and the child support scheme, as the Prime Minister has directed, I can advise the House that section 121 has come up frequently. Whilst I am not saying that the bill that I propose is the total answer, I think the value of having it on the table is that others can look at it and, if they find fault with it, suggest ways in which it might be changed or amended. Accordingly, I seek leave to table this bill.
Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and I thank Minister Anthony for his courtesy. I also wanted to talk a little bit about the Army Reserve in today's grievance debate. I have always said in this House that the report of the committee chaired by the honourable member for Hawker, From phantom to force, was a very important report. One of its recommendations essentially said that all units in the Army should be capable of being replicated. In other words, you should have one unit being deployed, one training up and one resting. I was absolutely staggered that the government actually rejected this. I repeat that: the government actually rejected this. I fear that one of the reasons they did that was the hollowness in the Army.

speech.para: It is a matter of record that the Defence Subcommittee, of which I am a member, has sought for quite some time to get Army to produce the Army sustainability model, which allows the government to—I presume—reject what has been a fairly standard proposition. I am making a public plea to the Prime Minister to provide details of the Army sustainability model, because I fear that what the model shows is that Army is dependent upon nonexistent units to sustain itself—nonexistent units in the second round and nonexistent units in the third round. I believe it is utterly essential that the Defence Subcommittee be provided, at the earliest opportunity, with the information that it has been requesting for some time.

I urge the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence to make a ministerial statement about the reserves. We have heard a lot about high readiness reserves, and I fully support the development of the reserve response group. However, whilst this comprises high readiness reserves in high readiness units, these are blended units; they are not formed units. There will be other reservists designated high readiness. I point out to the House that this is a personal category of effectiveness. You do not become a high readiness reserve by interacting in a formed unit that is high readiness. To have individual training is one thing, but without being able to train with other reservists who are equally high readiness reservists in formed units and not blended units causes great concern. The high readiness reserves in the reserve response group, other than the commandos, train not in their high readiness unit but in their normal unit. Their high readiness unit category is overlaid on their normal unit. They get no extra funding—this has been done with no extra funding—and no extra equipment. Given that we are spending some $950 million a year, according to the Auditor-General's report on Army Reserves, this is a real matter of concern.

I urge the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence to come into the House and make a ministerial statement about the changes that have been made to the reserves and where she sees the reserves heading in the future. I think the 16,000 reservists thoroughly deserve a ministerial statement. There has not been one made since a whole series of changes were announced, purporting to improve the reserves.

talker.name: Stone, Dr Sharman, MP
Dr STONE
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —On 29 August 2003, the Council of Australian Governments, or COAG, met and considered amongst other things a most significant issue—a national water initiative. This is a balanced approach to the issue of sustainable, efficient and effective management of the country's water resources. It is a major step forward. It was welcomed in particular by water users in my electorate who were increasingly despairing at the capture of the debate by those whose argument has not been informed by good data.

speech.para: Many have been rightly concerned that the environmental flow debate has been crudely pitched at extra water volume alone, without reference to flow rates, water temperature or seasonality. Irrigation water use has too often been labelled as wasteful or inefficient, without any analysis of the performance of individual industry sectors, comparisons over time or between states or within states.

I will quote from a document being presented today by the Ganawarra Shire in the Murray electorate to the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, Minister Truss, who I know will be most understanding of the sentiments expressed. The shire says they have no confidence in the current Living Murray process because:

quote.para: ... increased flows have been recommended—

speech.para: that is, by the Wentworth Group and the Murray-Darling Basin Commission—

quote.para: without specifically identifying river health needs or considering social and economic impacts, and other options for resolving water quality problems have been either ignored or rejected without cost benefit analysis. The whole process has been driven by narrow sectional interests.

speech.para: It is understandable that there was a collective sigh of relief in northern Victoria when the interdependencies of human and natural capital were acknowledged in the opening paragraph of the National Water Initiative. It reads:

quote.para: The Council of Australian Governments agreed that there is a pressing need to refresh its 1994 water reform agenda to increase the productivity and efficiency of water use, sustain rural and urban communities, and to ensure the health of river and groundwater systems.

speech.para: Many of us have long argued that greater productivity and efficiency of water use in healthier systems is essential if Australian rural and urban communities are to survive with anything like their current amenity. But it is a closed loop because only viable communities can sustainably manage ecosystems, which are overwhelmingly in the hands of private land managers, in Australia. This is now recognised by the Murray-Darling Basin Commission in its consultative and research work. I believe that my electorate will be better pleased when they hear the Murray-Darling Basin Council outcomes in their forthcoming meeting.

The National Water Initiative saw the states, territories and the Australian government committing to substantial funding and a way forward that will implement a sturdy framework for water access entitlements that encourages investment and maximises the economic value created from water use, while ensuring that there is sufficient water available to maintain healthy rivers and aquifers.

The Hon. John Howard has been one of the few Australian Prime Ministers to lead the nation to look beyond the limitations of the Australian Constitution. The Constitution leaves natural resource management fairly and squarely in the hands of the states and territories. The last century of division of responsibility between competing jurisdictions has seen catchments like the Eyre Basin and the Murray-Darling Basin dissected into a mishmash of rules and regulations or, in some cases, simply a free-for-all for water. Stressed streams and overallocation of surface and ground waters has resulted in serious resource degradation. Most Australians admit and acknowledge this today—in particular, my farming community which was amongst the first in Australia to comprehensively address their salinity problems, some 20 years ago. Total catchment management or integrated catchment management is a concept which, for at least 30 years, has been considered fundamental to any rational or sustainable management of natural resources. In Australia, however, only lip-service has been paid to the concept. Jurisdictions maintain cross-border impermeability. The situation between jurisdictions has made the notion of total catchment management a mockery.

Most importantly, this new National Water Initiative commits all Australian governments to regimes to protect environmental assets and ecosystem health on a whole of basin aquifer or catchment scale. This is a major step forward, and it is what we are aiming to achieve through our Natural Heritage Trust mark II total catchment natural resource management agenda. The COAG initiative also acknowledges that water trading can help transfer water to its highest value use but that trade in the same water systems is often stymied by current states' rules and regulations.

There is concern that often the high-security water from the same source is delivered at different prices and in different product categories. For example, at the opening of the 2003 irrigation season on the Murray River, New South Wales irrigators were given access to 100 per cent of their high-security water entitlement out of Hume and Dartmouth dams. Victorian irrigators were offered a zero allocation from their high-security water right out of those same two dams, and South Australian high-security water licensees were offered 65 per cent of volume entitlement from that same source.

While Victorian irrigators have now been moved up to join their New South Wales counterparts to access 100 per cent of their entitlements, South Australia remains at 65 per cent of water from the same source with the same security. Victorian and New South Wales Murray system irrigators pay bulk water charges as part of their water price. In South Australia, that state's taxpayers pay the bulk water charges. In Victoria, those who buy water in a temporary transfer do not pay bulk water charges while those who buy permanently allocated water do. In the COAG water initiative it is also stressed that water should be sold, whether to urban or to rural consumers, at full cost recovery.

Allocation and price inequities mean that primary producers often cannot compete on a level playing field where different rules apply to the same product and the same system of water. We obviously have a problem when primary producers have to compete in the same food and fibre markets.

Victoria has the longest established and most developed of the Australian water markets at this point in time. In 1984 the Victorian Public Bodies Review Committee first proposed tradeable water entitlements to address economic and institutional problems associated with water allocation. Water trading was also seen to be a sound way to address environmental issues associated with irrigation water use efficiency and salinity. The season of 1987-88 saw the first water trading trials.

In Victoria's water market it is now well understood and accepted that water trading can serve irrigators very well. In the drought season of 2002-03, 65 per cent of all irrigation water applied in the Shepparton region was traded between water owners either temporarily or permanently. But even with 10 years experience, Victoria's extensive markets for water can benefit from further evolution and development, and the National Water Initiative will give this a strong impetus.

For example, a sale of two per cent of permanent water out of a northern Victorian irrigation district triggers an immediate moratorium on any further trade of water out of that district for the season in consideration of potential stranded assets and other socioeconomic impacts. This two per cent trigger has now been reached for the first time in one district, the Pyramid Hill area, in northern Victoria. In this district, those depending on the permanent sale of all or part of their water right are now stranded, so to speak, despite their wish to realise on their assets, to retire or to move their property enterprise elsewhere, or they may be in urgent need to retire debt amassed as a consequence of the worst drought on record. Thus a 10-year-old policy that recognised the potential problem of stranded assets failed to deal with all third-party impacts, despite the best intentions of water users and the water authority when the rules and regulations were introduced 10 years ago. Also, quite obviously property rights to the Victorian storages sales pool will need urgent clarification in the new world order of entitlements as a share of the total resource, and in the light of the COAG water initiative, which stresses the need for all water access entitlements to be clarified in relation to security and in transparency.

The Ganawarra Shire, in speaking to Minister Truss today, has stressed that it does not want any decision to increase environmental flows until we fully understand river health, the socioeconomic impacts of increased flows and the potential benefits of all options, including engineering. I would be able to reassure my Ganawarra Shire constituents, as would Minister Truss, that that is absolutely the intention of the Murray-Darling Basin Council and this new National Water Initiative. I also register a concern of the Food Bowl Community Alliance in northern Victoria: they want a moratorium on any interstate permanent trade in water or between any environmental agency irrigators purchasing water. They believe, quite rightly, that they should not have such trading until all states have the same market robustness and capability and therefore can offer the same access to environmental flows. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —For much of the structure and content of this speech, I wish to acknowledge the work of Robin Ryan in his report Building a national vocational education and training system. For most of its history, Australia as a nation has been short of industrial and technical skills. It is true that technical training had its roots established in the working classes of this nation—as it is also true that much of the technical training has been stuffed up by middle-class dilettantes. That unfortunately remains true today. Technical education in each of the states has a history of state control. Nevertheless technical education has been universally regarded as a key component of nation building. Technical education needs national interest and liberalism to coincide, and should not be forced to choose between the two goals to arrive at a dominant policy.

speech.para: The truth is that technical education has always fallen off the national agenda until a crisis of some form or another has arisen. For much of the last 100 years, technical education has oscillated between two opposing policies: it is either seen as an instrument of economic development to meet the needs of industry—employment—or it meets the aspirations of individual self-development and creativity. It should do both. Technical education has been driven by national crises, depressions and world wars. It did have a brief ascendency in the 1970s to meet public policy based on a more equitable society, and there was a quick dip in the late 1980s and early 1990s into corporate managerialism. The term `technical education' has now been replaced with `vocational education and training', which at least reflects the dichotomy of the two public policy positions. But what drives vocational education in this country? What are the competing value systems? State control of technical education has not had a great history; nor has Commonwealth control. It is amazing that the first debate on technical education did not occur in this House until 1945.

The Minister for Postwar Reconstruction at the time, John Dedman, actually favoured a stronger role for the Commonwealth in technical education. Unfortunately, this was not shared by his Labor cabinet colleagues. That was a great pity for, after the 1949 federal election—the election of Menzies—no policy consensus existed for an interventionist style of government into the states. John Walker, the best postwar director of education of any state in Australia, but who unfortunately lasted only 18 months in South Australia, did implement progressive policies to advance technical education in that state. However, this was the exception rather than the rule. Technical education next came to the forefront in 1974 under the social activism policies of the Whitlam government. These policies continued until the mid-1980s, when again TAFE and technical education fell off the public agenda. It was revived again in October 1991 by John Dawkins, who cheekily proposed a Commonwealth takeover of TAFE. This caused a monumental blue at the time, but at least it put TAFE on the national agenda again. I am in no doubt whatsoever that TAFE, along with primary and junior secondary education, requires fundamental reform.

May 2003 signalled the 30th anniversary of the Karmel report, heralded in its day as a watershed educational blueprint for the future. In hindsight, it did no such thing. It advantaged higher education, private education and senior secondary academic education, seriously compromised TAFE and underresourced public primary, public secondary and, in particular, vocational education. I am not for a moment suggesting the Karmel report did this deliberately. Of course it did not, but that is what in fact happened. This highlights the need for major educational reform in technical and public education in this country. Quite frankly, the states are not up to it. In 1945, John Dedman was right. In the 1950s, John Walker was right. And in October 1991, John Dawkins was right. As Robin Ryan suggests in his report:

quote.para: A trigger device is required to initiate fundamental change.

speech.para: That trigger device could be the current Minister for Education, Science and Training, except that I am not confident he has the necessary belief, value of process and technical skill to achieve what would be a world-first in technical education. We all know that the operation of government is not easy. The implementation of good policy depends on the possibility of the opening of policy windows. But this federal government and all the state governments in this country, despite their protestations, are literally swimming in money. They are the highest taxing governments in our history. Good public policy windows happen only occasionally and then only for a short time. We all understand that sometimes people miss the point. It is a bit like the honeymoon couple who drove from Adelaide along the Great Ocean Road to Melbourne. Feeling romantic, the young groom placed his hand on his bride's knee. `You can go further, darling,' she said—so the groom drove to Sydney. This government is a lot like that groom. It misses the point. It misses the opportunity. It ignores the fact that solutions need to be coupled with ideas. That is the way real change, dinkum change, change that will advantage the nation really occurs.

My grievance is this: education under this government never reaches high politics. It is always low politics—very low politics indeed. In high politics, initiatives, efficiencies, equality, liberty, merit and the mobilisation of all of those things are in the ascendency. In low politics, partisanship, bias, exploitation, ignorance of need, lies and misrepresentation of the truth come to the fore and public policy opportunities are lost. In fact, one Financial Review writer—I think it was Tony Harris—recently said that almost perverted discourse happens when this government talks about education. `Perverted discourse' is not a great description of the government's role in education. The education public policy of the current government is deficient. I challenge anyone on the government side to stand up and tell us what the initiatives are in public primary, secondary—particularly junior secondary—and technical education. Where are they? The educational rhetoric of this government is geared to do one thing and one thing only—keep public and technical, or vocational, education off the public agenda. That is what the bias is, and this government is biased against public and technical, or vocational, education.

To sum up, public policy, in whatever area, needs solutions, needs to be aligned and needs to be coupled with ideas, not rhetoric. As Robin Ryan states in his report, that demands three values to be present. The first is efficiency, the second is equality and the third is freedom—something that ought to be precious in a democratic society such as ours. The truth is that this government has abandoned the education market for the majority of Australians. There is a concentration on one, 10 or 30 per cent of the market but never all of it—the one per cent being the category 1 schools, the 10 per cent being the independent schools and the 30 per cent being the private system. That is not efficiency. That is failure, and in that failure they ought to have a strike recorded against them. If the poor, the disabled, the dislocated, the regional and the provincial are ignored, that is not equality. That too is a failure. But that is symptomatic of the Howard government in education. That is two strikes. For this government the third value, freedom, is exclusive, not inclusive. For this government, freedom is a narrow freedom. It is the freedom of choice based on the ability to pay. That is the most self-indulged of all the freedoms. There is no freedom if merit is ignored, and merit is ignored by this government. That too is failure. That is three strikes against this government—failure in efficiency, failure in equality and failure in freedom. The great sadness is that it does not need to be so, and the fact is that it makes it indefensible as far as the national interest of this nation is concerned. It is time the government lifted its game in education and applied some balance across the whole sector, not just one part of it.

talk.start.para: —I have spoken in this House before on the issue of double jeopardy and the need to reform what is an outdated 800-year-old law. The presence of this law in our states' legal systems in its current form has resulted in at least one grave injustice and certainly has the potential to create many more. This is primarily because this law has not kept pace with technological developments in investigative techniques and can prevent a retrial occurring even where previously unavailable evidence can prove a suspect's guilt.

speech.para: I am speaking today particularly to outline the outcome of a petition I have been working on since last speaking on this issue and to express my profound disappointment at the Queensland Labor government's continued inability to act on this issue. Additionally, I am thoroughly disappointed at the Queensland government's willingness to use the current preparation of a national discussion paper on this issue as an excuse not to express any clear position. My message today to the Queensland Premier, Peter Beattie, and his Attorney-General, Rod Welford, is that you need to have the courage to make a commitment and a decision, just as New South Wales has made a commitment and a decision, that double jeopardy will be reformed. I would also urge those involved in the preparation of the national discussion paper to consider the results of the Queensland petition and to keep this process moving, hopefully towards much-needed reform.

The reason I feel so strongly about this issue is that I have some understanding of a case that highlights the need for double jeopardy reform. The case I am speaking of is that of Deidre Kennedy, who was murdered in 1973. Deidre was a 17-month-old shy baby girl from Ipswich in Queensland and was brutally murdered just over 30 years ago. As a baby Deidre was taken from her home during the night. She was bashed, sexually assaulted and thrown onto the roof of a public toilet block. Raymond John Carroll was convicted by a jury of Deidre's murder but was later acquitted on a legal technicality. He was convicted of perjuring himself at his first trial but was let off again on a legal technicality because the conviction was deemed to be double jeopardy.

The heartbreak felt by Mrs Kennedy and other brave members of the Kennedy family is absolutely unimaginable. I can tell you that there is no doubt in the mind of Mrs Kennedy or anybody with knowledge of this case that the evidence proves the suspect's guilt—no doubt at all. Yet, 30 years after the crime, this killer is allowed to walk free and taunt Mrs Kennedy by living in her local area and shopping at her workplace.
