subdebateinfo.title: Australian Securities and Investments Commission: NRMA Ltd
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1876)

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 14 May 2003:

question.para: (1) In light of the NRMA's substantial financial losses, the recently announced increases in membership fees and reduction in member services, will the Treasurer be directing the Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) to investigate the following representations made in the 2000 Information Memorandum issued to the 2 million members of NRMA Ltd:
(a) The NRMA will be in a strong financial position after the Proposal is implemented.
(b) Road service membership fees will not increase as a consequence of the Proposal.
(c) The Proposal is designed to allow membership fees to be maintained without increasing until 30 June 2001 ... Thereafter, it is expected that fees will be increased using the CPI as a guide.
(d) Existing road service benefits can be maintained.
(e) The proposal is also designed to allow current road and related motoring services and service levels to be maintained, if not improved; if not, why not.

(2) Given the substantial increases in insurance premium rates since the demutualisation of NRMA Insurance Limited, now known as IAG Limited, will ASIC investigate the following representations made in the 2002 Information Memorandum issued to the 2 million members of NRMA Limited:
(a) Insurance premium rates will not increase as a consequence of the Proposal.
(b) Claims management principles will not increase as a consequence of the Proposal; if not, why not.

(3) Will ASIC investigate whether the use of the NRMA logo by Mr Ross Turnbull and his team of candidates on a brochure sent to all NRMA members prior to the 2002 AGM was unauthorised, and if it was unauthorised, will ASIC also investigate the position in the light of the general law and the Corporations Act 2001, specifically the matter of directors' duties, as rule 16 of the constitution of the NRMA prohibits the unauthorised use of the company's logo without the approval of the board; if not, why not.

(4) Will ASIC investigate whether the said use of the NRMA logo by Mr Ross Turnbull and his team of candidates to solicit proxies constituted misleading and deceptive conduct in breach of the General law, the Corporations Act 2001 and/or the Trade Practices Act; if not, why not.

(5) Will ASIC investigate whether the financial resources of the NRMA were used lawfully for private advantage by Mr Ross Turnbull and his team of candidates, to gain appointments to the board of NRMA Ltd, by: (a) using the company's official voting pack mailed to the NRMA's 2 million members to distribute their unofficial proxy, (b) retaining PR consultants Jackson Wells Morris, to advise and conduct their election campaign, and (c) implementing a media campaign of self-promotion; if not, why not.

(6) Will ASIC investigate whether the decision to continue paying the legal fees of Mr Nicholas Whitlam for the appeal proceedings in the Supreme Court of NSW was unlawful, or inconsistent with prior board resolutions to cease all further such payments.

(7) Will ASIC investigate whether Mr Ross Turnbull breached any law, including the Crimes Act and the Corporations Act, by using an NRMA corporate credit card to pay for at least $50,000 of personal expenses incurred during his first 4 months as a Director; if not, why not.
(8) Will the Treasurer investigate the refusal of ASIC's chairman, Mr David Knott, to accept a petition addressed to him as Chairman and signed by nearly 1,000 NRMA members; if not why not.
(9) Will the Treasurer accept service of the petition; if not, why not.

(10) Can he say whether Mr Ross Turnbull, the current President of the NRMA, is: (a) a current member of the Liberal Party; (b) the same Mr Ross Turnbull who stood for Liberal Party preselection for the federal seat of Wentworth; and (c) the same Mr Ross Turnbull who attended the Liberal Party fund raiser at NSW Parliament House earlier this year; if so, can he say whether the NRMA paid for this attendance by the use of his NRMA corporate credit card or by any other means.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) No. ASIC actively considered these matters during September 2002. It was concluded that directors would have had a reasonable belief that these statements were correct at the time they were made. ASIC advises that there was insufficient evidence to conclude otherwise at the time.

(2) ASIC advises that, following detailed consideration of these matters, ASIC formed the view that there was insufficient evidence to conclude that the rise in premiums was as a result of the demutalisation process.

(3) and (5) ASIC has advised that it is currently making enquiries in relation to the brochure sent to NRMA members prior to the AGM held on 14 January 2003. These enquiries include consideration of the use of the NRMA logo in the brochure. The enquiries have not yet concluded. As the matter is under consideration, ASIC is unable to provide any further public comments at this stage.

(4) Except to the extent that it is relevant to ASIC's enquiries described in the response to question 3 above, ASIC does not propose to investigate whether the use of the NRMA logo by Mr Ross Turnbull and his team of candidates to solicit proxies constitutes misleading and deceptive conduct, on the basis that these matters fall outside ASIC's regulatory powers.

6) ASIC advises that it has made enquiries into this issue. It should be noted that, under section 199A(3) of the Corporations Act, an indemnity for legal costs in defending proceedings for a Court order brought by ASIC is allowed unless the grounds for making the order are found by the Court to have been established. Section 199A(4) of the Corporations Act extends the definition of proceedings to any appeal in relation to those proceedings.

(7) ASIC has advised that it is making enquiries into complaints about the alleged use by Mr Turnbull of his NRMA corporate credit card. These enquiries have not yet concluded. As the matter is under consideration, ASIC is unable to provide any further public comments at this stage.
(8) No. Such an investigation is not a function of the Treasurer.
(9) No. The petition is not addressed to the Treasurer.
(10) This does not come under the Treasurer's portfolio responsibilities.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 15 May 2003:

question.para: (1) Can the minister confirm that in letters dated 13 and 21 May 2002 he stated that Australia was favourably disposed to Taiwan being admitted to the World Health Organization (WHO) with observer status, but would only do so when it was clear a consensus supported such a move.
(2) Would consensus have to include the agreement of the People's Republic of China; if so, is the Minister able to say whether this is likely to be forthcoming.

(3) What other organisations or entities, such as the International Committee of the Red Cross, or quasi states, already enjoy observer status and did Australia support their accreditation to the WHO as observers; if so, how did Australia explain its support for these organisations or entities.

(4) Have the speedy spread of the SARS epidemic in Taiwan and the possibility of continued cross-infection between China and Taiwan via the busy cross-Strait trade and travel made the admission of Taiwan as an observer to the WHO even more urgent than before.

(5) Will the Government, at the commencement of the meeting of the WHO in Geneva on 28 May 2003, move to join the recent statements of the Japanese government, the EU, and the US Congress and bi-partisan private member's resolution moved by the Member for Fairfax and seconded by the Member for Lilley supporting the admission of Taiwan to the WHO as an observer.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) In the letters cited I stated that the Government understood and was sympathetic to Taiwan's desire to be admitted to the WHO. The Government's position remains unchanged. WHO practice is to decide the admittance of new members or observers through consensus of all members. Australia endorses the consensus approach, as it ensures that decisions represent the views of all members. We support resolution of the issue of Taiwan's participation by consensus.
(2) No. In UN practice, consensus means the absence of an express objection from any member. It does not require agreement; abstention is also possible.

To date, there have been objections from some WHO members, including the People's Republic of China (PRC), to Taiwan's bid. The issue of the PRC's policy on Taiwan's bid is one for the PRC Government.

(3) The following entities have observer status at the WHO: the Holy See, the Order of Malta, the International Committee of the Red Cross, the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies, and Palestine.

The Holy See, the Order of Malta, the International Committee of the Red Cross, and the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies were admitted as observers upon the invitation of the Director-General, with the consensus of the World Health Assembly (WHA). Australia supported this consensus, consistent with its objective that the membership of UN bodies should reflect the consensus view of their members.

Palestine was admitted as an observer under the name Palestine Liberation Organization in 1974, pursuant to WHA resolution 27.37. The resolution was adopted by a show of hands, and received 77 votes in favour, one against, and 16 abstentions. Individual members' votes are not recorded in votes conducted through a show of hands.

(4) Although not a member or observer, Taiwan is able to cooperate with the WHO on measures to combat the Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) epidemic. On 3 May, WHO officials arrived in Taiwan to assist its response to SARS. Disease prevention and control experts from Taiwan attended a WHO conference on SARS in Kuala Lumpur, 17-18 June. Australia has supported Taiwan's participation in further practical and technical measures to combat SARS. Taiwan has also been assisted by other agencies in its response to the SARS epidemic, such as the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Temporary quarantine measures designed to contain the movement of SARS across the Taiwan Strait, including mandatory quarantine periods and health inspections, were introduced to control the spread of SARS, similar to quarantine measure introduced in other SARS-affected localities.

(5) The World Health Assembly concluded in Geneva on 28 May. At the WHA, the matter of Taiwan's bid for WHO observership attained insufficient support in the General Committee, on which Australia is not represented, to gain a place on this year's WHA agenda. talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 29 May 2003:

quote.para: Has the rate of the pension to be paid to Dr Peter Hollingworth been calculated; if so, what is the amount of annual pension that will eventually be paid.

talk.start.para: —I am advised by my department of the following:

quote.para: The pension entitlement for a former Governor-General is provided for in the Governor-General Act 1974. The Act sets the basic pension at 60 per cent of the salary payable to the Chief Justice of the High Court. The basic pension is then reduced to take account of the superannuation surcharge.

The surcharge conversion factor is determined by the Scheme Trustee in accordance with advice from the Australian Government Actuary. The reduction cannot be more than 15%, that is, the minimum pension payable to the Governor-General will be 85 per cent of 60 per cent of the Chief Justice's salary. The actual pension amount will depend on a number of factors including the age of the beneficiary and his spouse. The resulting pension is indexed to the Chief Justice's salary and payable for life. It is fully taxable and treated as income for income tax purposes.
Dr Hollingworth is the first former Governor-General to be affected by the superannuation surcharge.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 3 June 2003:

question.para: (1) In respect of the Genetically Modified Organism (GMO) record kept by the Office of the Gene Technology Regulator (OGTR) and, in particular, “Dealings Not Involving Intentional Release (DNIR)” licence GMAC 5607 entitled “The use of virus vectors for gene silencing in plants (Virus Induced Gene Silencing)”, did the Genetic Manipulation Advisory Committee (GMAC), in issuing that licence, require the CSIRO to provide the name of the persons or the organisations that were to be the source or sources of the virus substances named in the dealings; if so, who, and/or which organisation or organisations were named as the source or sources of each of the virus substances named as a `parent organism in the GMO Record; if not, why not.
(2) Which of the virus substances listed in the licence were imported into Australia and when.
(3) Did the `monitoring and compliance mechanisms of the OGTR apply to the project; if not, why not.
(4) Were the conditions under which the licence was granted adhered to, and could the Minister provide copies of the reporting demonstrating such adherence.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) The virus source information was not required to be provided at the time of GMAC's consideration of the GMO dealing application. However, the OGTR has since obtained the following information in relation to DNIR5607. The viruses nominated under GMAC licence 5607 were: Tobacco mosaic virus, sourced from CSIRO Adelaide; Potato virus X, plasmid DNA imported from John Innes Institute United Kingdom; Brome mosaic virus, not acquired; Barley yellow dwarf virus, plasmid DNA imported from Iowa State University USA; Wheat streak mosaic virus, not acquired; Johnson grass mosaic virus sourced from La Trobe University Melbourne; and Foxtail mosaic virus, imported from American type culture collection USA, and United States Department of Agriculture, USA.

(2) In respect of the Potato virus X, the plasmid DNA was imported during April 1997; the Barley yellow dwarf virus was imported during July 1999; and the Foxtail mosaic virus was imported during August 2001 and November 2001.
(3) Yes.

(4) CSIRO facilities have been the subject of a number of inspections. There have been no instances of non-compliance, which compromised the containment of GMOs or posed a risk to human health and safety or the environment.
A summary of all monitoring conducted by the OGTR is included in the Quarterly Reports which are available from the OGTR website www.ogtr.gov.au . The Quarterly Reports are tabled in Parliament.

(2) ASIC is aware of a recent complaint made to it that answers this description. In order to ensure that all aspects of this matter were properly taken into account, ASIC reviewed its original decision in this case. Once the review was undertaken, AS

(3) IC again concluded that it had no proper role in this case. The circumstances outlined in this case did not identify a matter of critical importance to the financial services market. quote.para: Ultimately the individual concerned retains the option of pursuing private remedies through the court system and can seek appropriate legal advice. In this instance, the Law Society of Tasmania may be able to provide him with assistance in this regard.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 16 June 2003:

question.para: (1) Is the classification of an area as a “district of workforce shortage” determined by the doctor to population ratio; if not, on what basis is it determined.

(2) Does the Minister endorse the following assessment of her Parliamentary Secretary in response to my representations of 6 March 2003 on behalf of Dr Natalya Peker: “Port Kembla and Berkeley are located in the Wollongong (C) SLA, which lies within a metropolitan area. Current Medicare billing statistics show that the supply of general practitioners in the Wollongong (C) SLA is better than that currently experienced on average in Australia. Therefore, overseas trained doctors would not generally be granted exemptions that would allow them to provide Medicare eligible services at these locations.”; if so, why.

(3) Is the Minister aware that the doctor to population ratio in the electoral division of Throsby is below the national average and is now 1 doctor to every 1,362 people and that Berkeley currently has a doctor to population ratio of 1 doctor to 1,732 people; if so, (a) was this considered when making a determination as to whether or not Dr Peker should be granted an exemption to practice at Berkeley and issued a Medicare Provider Number; if not, why not, and (b) was this considered in regard to Berkeley being granted district of workforce shortage status; if not, why not.

(4) Is the Minister aware that in the electoral division of Throsby the number of doctors to population in each postcode district is: (a) 1 to 768 in 2502, (b) 1 to 5,150 in 2505, (c) 1 to 1,732 in 2506, (d) 1 to 1,308 in 2526, (e) 1 to 1,677 in 2527, (f) 1 to 1,219 in 2528, (g) 1 to 2,686 in 2529, and (h) 1 to 1,151 in 2530.
(5) Will the Minister declare Throsby a district of workforce shortage and issue Dr Peker a Medicare Provider Number; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Yes. The Minister's delegate in the Department of Health and Ageing may take into account some other factors such as whether a community is classified as rural or remote, and local special needs such as the presence of a significant Indigenous population.
(2) Yes. Current Medicare statistics indicate that the supply of general practitioners in the Wollongong (C) Statistical Local Area (SLA) is better than that experienced on average in Australia.

(3) (a) and (b). No. Doctor to population ratios are calculated at the level of SLAs. SLAs are the basic building blocks used by the Australian Bureau of Statistics' Australian Standard Geographic Classification (ASGC) system. The use of SLAs to report on doctor to population ratios is considered the most appropriate approach as it is the smallest standard geographic unit defined in the ASGC.
(4) Postcode districts are not used to determine districts of medical workforce shortage, which are assessed on the basis of SLAs.
(5) No. Electorates are not used as a basis for determining districts of medical workforce shortage.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 17 June 2003:

question.para: (1) Is the Minister satisfied that the loss of the Mirage A3-40 on 2 May 1986, which resulted in the death of Craig Mackelmann, has been adequately investigated.

(2) Is the Minister aware that statements made by the President of the Board of Inquiry (BOI), Air Commodore N Ford, to inquiries by the Ombudsman in 1991 and by Senator Durack in 1998, have been subsequently found to be inaccurate, and that Air Commodore Ford later changed his testimony before the Federal Court.

(3) Will the Government review and investigate fully the following matters in respect of which Air Commodore changed his testimony: (a) why the timing of radio transmissions at the time of a range breach by F/Lt Riley differ by seven seconds from the report of the Accident Investigation Team headed by Wing Commander Kindler; (b) was a breach of Range Standing Orders committed by F/Lt Riley; (c) why was there not a Range Safety Officer allocated to the supervision of firing at the time of the loss of A3-40; (d) did F/Lt Riley make an illegal call during a four second lapse in the response time, and if so, why was this not reported in either the reports of the Accident Investigation Team or the BOI; (e) why did the President of the BOI ask questions of the two civil pilots involved in the incident by letter only and not under oath as directed by the Convenor; (f) why did the President of the BOI fail to question the civil pilots about the range breach and their late response to it; (g) why, when evidence in writing was given by F/Lt McCormack that he fired his guns while on the Firing Detail, does the RAAF maintain that no guns were fired; (h) why was no proper accounting of returned ammunition ever produced by the RAAF; and (i) what evidence is there that F/Lt Riley was in the position that he claimed.
(4) Was Disciplinary action taken against Air Commodore Ford when he changed his testimony before the Federal Court; if so, what action was taken; if not, why not.

talker.name: Vale, Danna, MP
Mrs Vale
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes. The Mirage accident has been the subject of an Accident Investigation; Board of Inquiry; Coronial Inquest; Ombudsman Investigation; Review of Structural Management Practices; Senator the Hon Peter Durack, QC Review; Defence Science and Technology Organisation Aeronautical Maritime Research Laboratory Structural Integrity Review; and Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT). The matter has also been the subject of a considerable number of Freedom of Information requests. Any further investigation would be nugatory in consideration of time passed and the lack of any additional verifiable evidence.

(2) A review of the content of the AAT indicates that former Air Commodore Ford was confused as to his recollections of events following the Mirage accident in 1986 and the existence of the gun camera film exposed on the day of the accident and its numerous inquiries, investigations and reviews. The AAT found this to be understandable in consideration of being asked to provide information in 1998 about events that occurred 12 years earlier. Air Commodore Ford agreed that he had made errors when talking with the Defence Force Ombudsman and the AAT, having considered his evidence, it was found that his evidence should be treated as unreliable and given little weight. It should be noted that Air Commodore Ford was never questioned before a Federal Court, therefore, he could not have changed his testimony before one.

(3) No. It is not necessary, as Air Commodore Ford did not change his testimony. He answered all questions with what he felt was the truth at the time, which was later found to be unreliable and not regarded.

(a) No. The Administrative Appeals Tribunal, which sat four times during 1998 and made its final determination in 1999, was conducted to determine if Defence had done all in its power to locate missing audiotapes. The Administrative Appeals Tribunal was satisfied that that it was more than likely than not that the original audio tapes no longer exist and thus any reason for a seven second difference in timing within the tapes could never be established. Plausible reasons for the difference in timing have been considered, including that of playback on different recorders. The assertion that Flight Lieutenant Riley made a range breach is incorrect and inappropriate.
(b) No.

(c) There was a Range Safety Officer present during this mission. Mass and Sortie briefings for air-to-air Gunnery activities are very specific that the `Formation Lead' is the Range Safety Officer. The aircraft towing the air-to-air banner also has Range Safety Officer responsibilities inherent with its role.
(d) No. The timings of calls made by members of the formation was not regarded as pertinent to the accident investigation.
(e) It would take an inordinate amount of time and resources to research and respond to this question due to the passage of time.
(f) It would take an inordinate amount of time and resources to research and respond to this question due to the passage of time.

(g) In the context of an extensive departmental Freedom of Information (FOI) search in 1999 for alleged gun camera cine film, Flight Lieutenant McCormack made comment in an e-mail message from overseas that he recollected having fired his guns. In his report to the Director of FOI at the time, the then Deputy Chief of Air Force made comment that irrespective of whether of not Flight Lieutenant McCormack fired his guns during the 2 May 1986 exercise, `on balance, the McCormack statement is not supported by extensive and thorough records searches undertaken by the Air Force'.
(h) It would take an inordinate amount of time and resources to research and respond to the question due to the passage of time.

(i) Evidence taken by the Accident Investigation Team and the Board of Inquiry would show that Flight Lieutenant Riley was where he claimed. There is no evidence to suggest that Flight Lieutenant Riley was in any other position.

(4) As stated in answer to part 2, Air Commodore Ford was never questioned in front of a Federal Court, therefore, it was assumed that this question refers to his appearance before the AAT. No disciplinary action was taken against him. Also, as stated in answer to part 3, he did not intentionally answer any question with other than what he felt was the truth at the time. Air Commodore Ford is no longer a member of the Royal Australian Air Force.

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 19 June 2003:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 23 June 2003:

talk.start.para: asked the Acting Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources, upon notice, on 24 June 2003:

question.para: (1) Can he provide an estimate for when Australian petroleum production will fall short of demand; if so, how confident is he that his estimate is correct; if not, why not.

talker.name: Hockey, Joe, MP
Mr Hockey
talker.role: Minister for Small Business and Tourism

talk.start.para: —The Acting Minister for the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Australian petroleum production already falls short of demand. In 2002-03, the shortfall of production over demand was 2,367.5 megalitres.

quote.para: It should be noted that because of geography and composition of Australian oil, a large proportion of domestic consumption is met by imported feedstock while, at the same time, a large proportion of Australian production is exported. In general, Australian crudes tend to attract higher prices than the cheaper alternatives. Around sixty per cent of the higher quality Australian crude oil is exported, while cheaper crudes are imported for used in Australian refineries.

answer.para: (2) Current estimates vary from thirty years (International Energy Agency) to more than forty years (World Energy Council).

quote.para: The ability of world petroleum production to continue to be able to satisfy demand will be driven by:

answer.para: · The rate at which demand increases
· The uptake of unconventional production from sources such as shale oil and gas to liquids
· The development of new and/or more efficient extraction technologies
· The development of more efficient fuel usage technologies
· New discoveries
· The price of oil, which will drive all of the above variables

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 25 June 2003:

question.para: (1) Can he explain his ministerial duty of care for children held in detention.

(2) In fulfilling this obligation, (a) with which State authorities is he or his department working, and (b) how is his responsibility to protect children divided between State agencies and organisations under his direct or indirect control.
(3) Can he explain the Government's policy on dealing with allegations of abuse of children in detention.
(4) What is the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs' definition of child abuse in this policy.
(5) For each migration detention centre, how many allegations of abuse of children in detention have been made for each of the past five years.
(6) In respect of each allegation, (a) what was the nature of the allegation, (b) was it substantiated, and (c) how did the department respond.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA), and its officers, have a general duty of care to all persons, adults and children, detained under the Migration Act 1958 (the Migration Act).

quote.para: DIMIA meets its duty of care to the diversity of people in detention, including children, through a comprehensive framework consisting of legislative and administrative measures, detailed contractual obligations with a Detention Services Provider (DSP), the Immigration Detention Standards (IDS) and a performance monitoring regime.
In general, all children in detention remain in the custody of their accompanying parent or parents.

The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs also has a specific duty to unaccompanied minors who are his or her wards under the Immigration (Guardianship of Children) Act 1946 (the IGOC Act). Under the IGOC Act, the Minister, as legal guardian of children who enter Australia unaccompanied by a parent or another adult carer, has the rights and powers which a parent may have over his or her own child.

The IGOC Act also empowers the Minister to delegate these guardianship powers and functions to any officer or authority of the Commonwealth or any state or territory. The Minister has delegated most of the powers and functions under the IGOC Act to DIMIA Managers and Deputy Managers in each detention facility, and to state or territory agencies responsible for child welfare.

answer.para: (2) In fulfilling this obligation:

quote.para: (a) DIMIA works with a number of agencies in relevant states including those responsible for child welfare, education, health and criminal law. For example, DIMIA liaises with the relevant state education agencies to ensure access to government educational services for detainee children.

(b) Various pieces of state legislation have effect in the detention environment, to the extent that this legislation is not inconsistent with Commonwealth legislation. State legislation relevant to children in detention is broadly that relating to welfare, education, health and criminal law. State agencies have access to Immigration Detention Facilities (IDFs), to the extent necessary to fulfil their statutory responsibilities, and DIMIA officers consult as appropriate with those agencies.

The involvement of relevant authorities in no way diminishes DIMIA's duty of care. Rather, these services strengthen the Commonwealth's ability to meet its responsibilities, particularly in the case of children in detention, by ensuring that decisions take account of all relevant information and advice from experts in that field.

Most states have a legislative framework which requires certain people dealing with children to make a notification or report if they suspect that a child is at risk of abuse or neglect. These people are known as `mandated notifiers'. In all states, IDF staff are required to act as if they were mandated notifiers, whether or not it is required under the State's child protection legislation.

DIMIA officers have responsibility for IGOC Act children while these children are in an IDF, or a Residential Housing Project such as that at Woomera. This delegated power ensures that DIMIA officers have appropriate legal authority to make decisions concerning the welfare and care of IGOC Act children while they are in IDFs. These officers draw upon the advice of people with expertise in child welfare such as psychologists and state and territory child welfare authorities.

The situation in relation to the Minister's delegations to state child welfare agencies varies from state to state. The Minister has written to all state child welfare Ministers proposing that their IGOC Act delegations be amended so that their agencies formally take responsibility for such children only once they have been moved out of an IDF.

As at August 2003, officers of certain state and territory child welfare agencies have delegated responsibility only once IGOC Act children are moved out of an IDF, while others have delegated responsibility in relation to all IGOC Act children in the state or territory.

Certain officers of the child welfare agencies in the Australian Capital Territory, Queensland, South Australia, Tasmania and Western Australia have delegated responsibility for IGOC Act children when:

answer.para: · they are in immigration detention in alternative detention arrangements made between DIMIA and the relevant state or territory governments (such as foster care); or
· they are not in immigration detention.

quote.para: Delegations of officers of child welfare agencies in New South Wales, the Northern Territory and Victoria include guardianship responsibility for all IGOC Act children, including those in IDFs. In practice, however, officers from these agencies usually exercise the delegated responsibilities for these children only when they are no longer in an IDF.

answer.para: (3) DIMIA and the DSP have in place a comprehensive range of policies and practices which aims to ensure the safety and protection of all children in immigration detention. These policies and practices operate within a legislative framework that includes both the Migration Act and state child welfare legislation.

quote.para: The development of Memoranda of Understanding (MOUs) with state child welfare authorities in relation to this matter is a priority for DIMIA. Such an MOU with the South Australian Department of Human Services was signed on 6 December 2001. The finalisation of MOUs with state child welfare authorities in New South Wales, Victoria, and Western Australia is being actively pursued.

DIMIA takes all allegations of abuse of children in detention extremely seriously. DIMIA requires that all incidents, allegations or reasonable suspicions of abuse or assault of children are reported, both to the local child welfare agencies and, under the detention services contract, to DIMIA. In most states, the child welfare agency will then decide if other parties, such as the police, need to be involved.

In cases of alleged abuse, DIMIA also requires the DSP to ensure appropriate professional counselling is given to both the alleged victim and alleged perpetrator. A plan for the ongoing management of the people involved in the alleged incident is required, including consideration of transferring either party to another area within the IDF or to another IDF.

The DSP also has procedural guidelines in place for its staff. These guidelines include information on dealing appropriately with assault, sexual assault, serious medical incidents and child protection. The DSP's policies take account of, and are appropriately tailored to each state's child welfare arrangements. As part of the contract management arrangements, DIMIA reviews the DSP's training programs to ensure that these cover the State legislation and DIMIA's requirements regarding the reporting of allegations or reasonable suspicions of abuse or assault of children.

answer.para: (4) The definition of child abuse is a matter for the relevant State child welfare authorities. In practice, DIMIA has procedures in place for reporting to the state welfare agencies all instances where there may be concern for the welfare of children, including the appropriateness of care arrangements, instances where parental behaviour requires intervention, and instances where medical conditions require assessment, as well as alleged or actual incidents of sexual or physical assault.

(5) Information compiled for the period 1 October 1999 to 30 November 2000 was included in the Report of Inquiry into Immigration Detention Procedures by Philip Flood AO, tabled in parliament on 27 February 2001. Relevant information within that report is:
· 1.1 Terms of Reference,
· 1.3 Widest possible meaning of the term `abuse',
· 6.3 Incidents assessed as meeting the Terms of Reference,
· 6.6 Table 5 - Cases Examined - 1 December 1999 to 30 November 2000;and

quote.para: Annex G Summary of Australasian Correctional Management incident reports by centre.

Following on from the period covered in this Report, Table A below provides the number of notifications to relevant state government agencies for the period 1 December 2000 to 19 May 2003 for each IDF.

answer.para: (6) To answer this question fully in relation to each individual allegation would involve a manual examination of each detainee's file. This would be a substantial and unreasonable diversion of the agency's resources from its normal operations. In general:

quote.para: (a) The broad categories of the nature of the incidents have been provided in Table A.
(b) For the period 1 December 2000 to 19 May 2003, DIMIA can advise that relevant state police have issued cautions on six occasions and charges have been laid on one occasion.

(c) All incidents of concern involving children are dealt with promptly. Each case concerning the safety of a child is dealt with on an individual basis. DIMIA officers and DSP staff are required to notify the relevant child welfare agencies of any instances involving minors where there is concern for the minor.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 25 June 2003:

question.para: (1) In 1955, did the NSW Government transfer the land formerly known as Gan Gan Army Camp in the electoral division of Paterson to the Commonwealth; if so, what price was paid.
(2) Has the Commonwealth now sold the land; if so, (a) at what price, (b) to whom, and (c) has the real property title transaction reached settlement.
(3) Was there a tender process and what are the details including time-frame of that tender offer.
(4) Did Port Stephens Shire Council offer to purchase the land; if so, what was its intended purpose for the land.

talker.name: Vale, Danna, MP
Mrs Vale
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Advice from Defence's legal representative on this matter, Phillips Fox, is that the survey plan for Primary Application 40695 was dated August 1954, but the certificate of title, the Torrens title, was not issued until 14 May 1959. The title is clear that there are no restrictions or qualifications to disposal.

quote.para: Phillips Fox advise that there is no clear audit trail on the documentation surrounding the transfer or sale. Searches to date have not identified a sale price. Phillips Fox advise that further searches would take considerable time, incur considerable expense and that an anticipated completion date could not be provided.

answer.para: (2) Yes.
(a) The sale price is Commercial-In-Confidence until the title transfer has been registered.
(b) Details of the purchaser are currently Commercial-In-Confidence until the title transfer has been registered.

(c) Legal settlement took place on Friday 27 June 2003. The transfer has not yet been registered and this could take more than three months. Until registration occurs the details are not in the public domain.

(3) Yes. Advertising commenced on 29 March 2003. Various newspapers were utilised including the Newcastle Herald, The Post, and the Sydney Morning Herald. Tenders were originally scheduled to close on 3.00pm 19 May 2003, but this was subsequently extended until 2.00pm 30 May 2003.

(4) Yes. Port Stephens Council made an application for priority sale consideration on 18 January 2002. In the Council submission the reason for acquisition is quoted as “...for the enjoyment of the broader community...”. Council did not identify a proposed future use for the site. The Council submission had significant deficiencies and Council was requested to revise and resubmit their submission on 8 April 2002. Despite a number of requests to do so, Council did not revise or resubmit their priority sale submission and on 4 October 2002 Council were formally advised that their priority sale consideration was withdrawn and that the site would be sold on the open market.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 25 June 2003:

question.para: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 1503 (Hansard, 14 May 2003, page 14574), which public hospitals in Australian are equipped with an Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) unit but do not provide Medicare eligible MRI services.
(2) What was the outcome of the recent negotiations between the Department of Health and Ageing and the Diagnostic Imaging (DI) profession.
(3) Will Concord Repatriation General Hospital be granted a licence to operate a Medicare eligible MRI unit; if so, when, if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) The Commonwealth does not have a comprehensive list of Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) units that are not eligible for Medicare rebates, nor does it have reliable information on ineligible units in public hospitals.

(2) The outcome of the recent negotiations between the Department of Health and Ageing and the Diagnostic Imaging profession was that a new Radiology Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) was finalised and took effect on 1 July 2003. Key features of this MoU are that it provides for:
· Medicare funded MRI to be fully managed under the MoU; and
· collaborative work with the Radiology profession to improve access to MRI.

(3) It is not possible to indicate when, or if, the MRI services provided at Concord Repatriation General Hospital will be eligible for Medicare rebates. The Government will work collaboratively with the Radiology profession under the new Radiology MoU to identify future priorities for MRI. It is envisaged that future processes in this area will build upon the previous work and advice provided by the MRI Monitoring and Evaluation Group (MEG).

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 25 June 2003:

question.para: (1) Further to part (7) of the answer to question No. 884 (Hansard, 22 October 2002, page 8402), who are the members of the Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) Monitoring and Evaluation Group (MEG).

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) The Chair of the Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) Monitoring and Evaluation Group (MEG) is Professor John Blandford. In the past, the MEG has included the following expertise:
· a health economist;
· an official from the Department of Health and Ageing;
· a radiology expert;
· a State and Territory health official from the Australian Health Minister's Advisory Council;
· an official from the Health Insurance Commission; and
· a consumer.
The MEG is currently being reconstituted in line with relevant provisions of the new Radiology Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) and the membership of the Group is still to be finalised.

(3) The Department has been advising the Minister on an ongoing basis about a range of issues regarding MRI units, including MEG advice and progress with negotiations on the new funding agreement which is now in place. However in light of the need to negotiate with the radiology profession the new funding agreements which were signed in June 2003, the last meeting of the MEG was in July 2002. The MEG has also met on the following dates since March 2000:
· 16 November 2001;
· 17 August 2001;
· 4 April 2001;
· 9 March 2001;
· 2 March 2001;
· 12 February 2001; and
· 12 December 2000.

(4) The specific advice of the MEG is strictly confidential. However, broadly speaking, previous advice has indicated that access to Medicare funded MRI in metropolitan Sydney is above the national average and that this area is therefore not the highest relative priority for additional services.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 25 June 2003:

question.para: (1) Can the Minister confirm that (a) the Blandford Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) Review of March 2000 recommended an increase of seven Medicare eligible units in the year commencing July 2000, and (b) the Government approved six additional Medicare eligible units in September 2001.
(2) Will the Minister consider providing an MRI licence for MRI units at all tertiary hospitals, including Concord Repatriation General Hospital; if so, when, if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) (a) The Review of Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) recommended an increase of up to seven additional Medicare eligible MRI units in the year following the release of the report of the Review.
(b) I can confirm that six additional Medicare eligible units were approved as a result of a tender process completed in 2001.

(2) Medicare eligibility is not necessary for MRI units to be established at tertiary hospitals, such as Concord Repatriation General Hospital. State and Territory Governments are responsible for ensuring access to MRI for patients admitted to public hospitals and are able to provide MRI units in these hospitals using their own revenue or using grants provided by the Commonwealth for hospital care. Medicare eligibility would not assist in providing services for such patients, as Medicare rebates are not payable to patients admitted to public hospitals.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 25 June 2003:

quote.para: Further to the answer to question No. 1077 (Hansard, 4 February 2003, page 10815), has the Department of Health and Ageing found a basis for providing the diabetic drugs Avandia and Actos on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) while containing the budgetary risk to the Commonwealth; if so, (a) what are the details of this agreement and (b) when will Avandia and Actos be included on the PBS; if not, why not

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 26 June 2003:

question.para: (1) Is the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) required to cover its operating costs entirely from the licence, inspection and registration fees it charges.
(2) Is it the case that the TGA compliance branch employs only 11 auditors nationally; if not, (a) how many does it employ, and (b) does the TGA propose to increase that number.

(3) Is the TGA compliance branch well behind in its audit program; if so, (a) how far behind is the TGA in its audit program, and (b) does this leave open the possibility of further manufacturing standard failures as recently experienced with Pan Pharmaceuticals; if not, why not.

(4) Has the delay in the audit program been exacerbated by the adoption in August 2002 of a new industry code of practice requiring a longer audit process; if so, has the TGA received additional resources to allow it to administer the new code and, if it has not, why not.
(5) How quickly is the TGA responding to manufacturers' replies to audit reports.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Since the 1998-1999 financial year, the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) has been a full cost recovery agency for all activities that fall within the scope of the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989. This includes regulation of the therapeutic goods industry, the TGA's public health responsibilities, the provision of information to consumers and TGA's support for industry generally (ie. facilitation of exports and international harmonisation of standards).

quote.para: The fees and charges levied by the TGA include those for the listing and registration of therapeutic goods on the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods (ARTG), as well as the audit and licensing of Australian manufacturers and certification of overseas manufacturers wishing to supply therapeutic goods in Australia.

answer.para: (2) (a) and (b) The TGA has an auditor pool of 44 officers, comprising fourteen (14) lead quality systems auditors and thirty (30) technical specialists to carry out audits of manufacturers of therapeutic goods supplied in Australia.

quote.para: Lead auditors are located in the Manufacturer Assessment Section of the Office of Devices, Blood and Tissues of the TGA in Canberra, Melbourne and Sydney. The TGA no longer has a Compliance Branch. Technical specialists are utilised where additional expertise is required at a particular audit. This expertise covers areas such as analytical chemistry, microbiology/virology, biotechnology, biomaterials, engineering and computer systems.

The TGA, in recognising the need to maintain an effective strategy of scheduling audits according to risk, is in the process of recruiting an additional four (4) lead auditors and training an additional eleven (11) specialist auditors.

In addition, non-auditing staff are being recruited to carry out the assessment of evidence for overseas manufacturers wishing to supply therapeutic goods to Australia, thus relieving lead auditors of this task and allowing them to focus on auditing alone.

answer.para: (3) (a) & (b) The TGA audit schedule is drawn up annually based upon manufacturer risk assessment and the available resources. At this stage the TGA has completed 41 per cent of audits of Australian and overseas manufacturers included on the 2003 schedule. It is expected the program will be satisfactorily completed with the engagement of the additional resources envisaged in (2) above.

quote.para: The risk management approach to the scheduling of audits gives high priority to auditing those manufacturers with a high-risk profile. The risk factors taken into account include:

answer.para: · type of products manufactured;
· results of previous Good Manufacturing Practice (GMP) audit;
· significant changes within the company, eg changes to key personnel, building, equipment or products;
· adverse medicine reaction reports, medicine problem reports and device incident reports;
· results of TGA Laboratories testing of random or targeted samples of products;
· recalls of products not meeting safety and /or quality standards;
· information from other agencies; and
· post-licensing surveillance investigations.

quote.para: The TGA uses the above information when scheduling audits and selects the most appropriate audit strategy, which may include an unscheduled audit. This approach is designed to more readily detect failures in compliance with manufacturing standards. The TGA's risk management audit strategy has been recognised as world leading by international organisations.

answer.para: (4) The content and principles of the Australian Code of GMP for Medicinal Products (August 2002) are very similar to the previous Australian Code of GMP for Medicinal Products (1990) other than for two additional requirements relating to marketing authorisation. These additional provisions require auditors to check that the product formulation matches that registered/listed with the TGA and that manufacturers validate their manufacturing and analytical processes and procedures.

quote.para: Although these are new requirements, they were always investigated during TGA audits under the old Code of GMP because of their importance in assuring product quality. Consequently, there has been no significant change to the length of the audit process and no adverse impact on audit waiting times or resourcing requirements.

answer.para: (5) The TGA has maintained its usual standard operating procedure approach of responding within a target time frame of one month to manufacturers' replies to audit reports. There has not been an increase in target time in the last ten years.

subdebateinfo.title: Education: Higher Education Contribution Scheme Contributions
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2109)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, Science and Training, upon notice, on 26 June 2003:

question.para: (1) Has he seen an article by Professor Peter Karmel from the Australian National University titled “Student contribution bigger than predicted” published in The Australian on 18 June 2003.

(2) Is it the case that the average student share of the cost of HECS-liable courses in 2005 is expected to be almost 40 per cent - a great deal higher than the 26.8 per cent described as the average student contribution towards the cost of their education on page 21 of the ministerial statement Our Universities - Backing Australia's Future.

(3) Is there a higher average student cost burden in any other OECD country in respect of publicly funded higher education institutions; if so, which countries and what are the average student burdens in each country.

talker.name: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP
Dr Nelson
talker.role: Minister for Education, Science and Training

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes.

(2) No. The 40 per cent figure used by Professor Karmel does not appear to take into account the Commonwealth subsidies involved in HECS. To calculate the average actual student contribution, the following subsidies need to be taken into account:
25% discount for upfront payers;
15% bonus for voluntary repayments;
debt write downs due to death of the debtor;
remission of HECS debts in special circumstances; and
provision for doubtful debt.

quote.para: On this basis, the Department of Education, Science and Training (DEST) has estimated the average actual student contribution to be 26.8 per cent in 2005 of total Commonwealth funding to universities.

answer.para: (3) DEST has advised that there is no strictly comparable data available on the average student cost burden across OECD countries of which we are aware.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 26 June 2003:

question.para: (1) In what year and under what guidelines did the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) give approval for the use of vitamin D3/Lipidiol in trials for the treatment of liver cancer.

(2) Which body authorises the trials of vitamin D3/Lipidiol for the treatment of liver cancer in Australian hospitals and which hospitals are currently involved in trials of vitamin D3/Lipidiol for liver cancer treatment.

(3) Is there an obligation for such trials to comply with guidelines established by the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC); if not, why not; if so, who is responsible for ensuring compliance with these guidelines.

(4) Is there a regime of full disclosure of potential side effects and risks involved in patient participation in the trials of vitamin D3/Lipidiol treatment for liver cancer; if so, who is responsible for such disclosure to patients.

(5) Is it conceivable that a patient could be part of a trial of vitamin D3/Lipidiol even though they had failed to meet all the specific selection criteria for the trial; if so, who would be held responsible for such a situation.

(6) Do protocols exist for the monitoring and evaluation of the trials of vitamin D3/Lipidiol in the treatment of liver cancer; if so, (a) who determines the protocols; (b) where can they be accessed, and (c) are such protocols standard throughout the hospital system.

(7) What avenues are open to the families of patients involved in trials should they wish to pursue specific concerns and complaints and which body is responsible for dealing with such concerns and complaints.

(8) If the TGA authorised the use of vitamin D3/Lipidiol in trials for the treatment of liver cancer, is it in a position to provide some public assessment of the efficacy of these trials; if so, what is that assessment; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Trials for the use of vitamin D3 in the treatment of liver cancer were notified to the TGA via the Clinical Trial Notification (CTN) Scheme in 1998 and 2002. Under the CTN Scheme TGA approval is not required for a trial to commence.

(2) There are two systems for clinical trials using unapproved medicines in Australia. The liver trials were notified to the TGA under the CTN Scheme, whereby a trial is reviewed by a Human Research Ethics Committee (HREC) and certain undertakings about compliance with international Good Clinical Practice (GCP) and the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) National Statement on Ethical Conduct of Research Involving Humans are obtained from the institution, the investigator, the trial sponsor and the HREC. Under the CTN Scheme the HREC is the authorising body.

quote.para: There is an alternate approval system based on TGA review of summary data, which is rarely used.
Only one hospital is currently involved in trials as discussed in (1), but the identity of the hospital would be regarded as commercial-in-confidence.

answer.para: (3) Yes. This is required as a condition of the exemption that allows the trial to use an unregistered good. The HREC is obliged to monitor this and the TGA has the power to seek information and to inspect sites to monitor that this is happening.

(4) It is a requirement under both the NHMRC National Statement and the Good Clinical Practice guidelines, that apply to all clinical trials operating under the therapeutic goods legislation, that all clinical trial subjects provide fully informed consent. The process of obtaining this should involve a full discussion of the potential risks and benefits of the treatment. Patient information forms are also usually provided. Consent information and documentation would be reviewed by the HREC as part of its approval and consent is usually obtained from subjects by the investigator.

(5) The protocol that is approved by the HREC outlines the inclusion and exclusion criteria that must apply for the trial. Enrolment of patients outside these criteria should not occur. In the unlikely event this occurred, the recruiting investigator would be responsible for notifying the HREC and sponsor.

(6) In order to comply with compulsory Good Clinical Practice guidelines and the NHMRC National Statement, any trials for the treatment of liver cancer should have a protocol that would include information on monitoring and evaluation. (a) Protocols are assessed for their adequacy as part of the HREC review. (b) While sometimes they may be provided to the public by the sponsor on request, they are regarded as commercial-in-confidence by many sponsors. (c) There are common features relating to all protocols in terms of the need to define inclusion and exclusion criteria, treatment dosage and duration, monitoring of subjects, etc, but actual protocols differ depending on the particular circumstances of the trial. For example; the nature of the condition and the treatment under investigation.

(7) Patients are given contact details of relevant trial personnel, usually the investigator and a local contact officer, when they are recruited into a trial. If they or their families have any concerns, these individuals are usually the first point of contact. The trial's investigators are required to deal with any concerns or complaints. Other points of contact would be the institution, the sponsor, the HREC, the NHMRC and the TGA.

(8) As these trials were conducted via the CTN scheme, no TGA “authorisation” was involved. As explained above, the TGA was only “notified” of the trials. There is no requirement for the TGA to be provided with the trial results, unless they form part of a registration dossier in the future. The HREC, however, should receive information on trial progress and results, as part of its monitoring.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 26 June 2003:

question.para: (1) Can he advise precisely which articles Australia is bound by under international law as an Occupying Power in Iraq.

(2) Can he explain the system that the Government has put in place to ensure that Australia's international obligations under the Geneva Convention are being met, including (a) who oversees that system, (b) who is physically making that assessment across Iraq, (c) where is that person or persons located and how often are they reporting, and (d) how many staff are working on that program.

(3) What is the Government's assessment (including that of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade) of Australia's success as an Occupying Power at ensuring the maintenance of law and order, health and medical facilities, and education.
(4) Does that assessment show that there areas for improvement; if so, what are the details.
(5) Can he advise what action Australia has undertaken with the other Occupying Powers to ensure that areas of non-performance are addressed.
(6) Can he advise what are the international legal sanctions that Australia would face if it does not discharge its duties as an Occupying Power effectively.
(7) How many Occupying Powers are there now in Iraq.

(8) Will he explain how the relationship between the Occupying Powers and the transitional authority established to discharge the responsibilities of the Occupying Powers works, both procedurally and on what legal basis there is for this relationship.
(9) Is Australia an equal power under international law in this transitional authority.

(10) How is the transitional authority structured, in particular, (a) where do Australian officials fit within this structure, (b) what is their role within this structure, and (c) what responsibilities are they discharging on behalf of Australia.

(11) Can he advise whether a timeline is envisaged, either by the transitional authority or by the Australian Government, for an act of political self-determination to be expressed by the Iraqi people and what Australia is doing to facilitate this.
(12) What is the total number estimated by (1) the USA and (2) the UK of (a) Iraqi and (b) Coalition (i) military and (ii) civilian fatalities arising from the Iraq conflict.
(13) Are these estimates publicly available; if not, why not.
(14) Is he able to say how many seriously injured people are in Iraqi hospitals; if not, why not.

(15) Is he or his department aware of concerns expressed by international NGO's about the health and medical situation in Iraqi hospitals; if so, is he able to say whether assessments made by those international NGOs are reliable.
(16) Can he indicate what chemical weapons have been located in Iraq.
(17) Can he advise whether weapons inspectors have discovered chemical munitions, anthrax, bacterial growth media or VX nerve agent in Iraq.
(18) Can he indicate what biological weapons have been located in Iraq.
(19) Does he stand by his statement on 4 November 2002 that “...we know Iraq is still producing chemical and biological weapons, and has endeavoured to produce nuclear weapons”; if not, why not.
(20) Can he advise whether there was any doubt expressed by the intelligence community in regards to Iraq's Weapons' of Mass Destruction (WMD) capability.
(21) Can he advise whether his department expressed any doubts to him or other members of the Government, or had any reservations regarding, allegations of Iraq's possession of WMD.
(22) What is the cost borne by the Government to send Australian weapons inspectors to Iraq to participate in searches for Iraqi WMD.
(23) How does this cost compare to the financial cost for Australia of the return of UNMOVIC and IAEA weapons inspectors to Iraq.

(24) Has he or his department had discussions with the US Government on the possibility of returning UN weapons inspectors to Iraq; if so, did he argue for the recommitment of UN weapons inspectors to Iraq.

(25) Has he had discussions with the Government of the United Kingdom on the possibility of returning UN weapons inspectors to Iraq; if so, did he argue for the recommitment of UN weapons inspectors to Iraq.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows :

answer.para: (1) Australia is one member of a coalition of countries contributing human and other resources to the Coalition Provisional Authority (CPA) presently in occupation of Iraq. In United Nations Security Council Resolution (UNSCR) 1483 of 22 May 2003, only the United States of America and the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland are named as Occupying Powers. Accordingly, these States have specific and special responsibilities and obligations under UNSCR 1483, the Geneva Conventions and the Hague Regulations. Australia is not named as an Occupying Power and thus does not bear the full burden of meeting these obligations.

(2) The Government established a legal watch group comprising the General Counsel (International Law), Office of International Law in the Attorney-General's Department, the Senior Legal Adviser of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, and the Director-General of the Defence Legal Service, as well as experts in international law drawn from each of those Departments. The legal watch group advises on legal matters of relevance to Australia's participation in the Coalition Provisional Authority (CPA). The group consults with its counterparts in the governments of the Occupying Powers in Iraq, namely the United States of America and the United Kingdom, to ensure that Australia's international legal obligations are taken into account.

In addition, Australia has assigned an experienced military lawyer to the Office of General Counsel in the CPA in Baghdad. The Australian Representative Office in Baghdad also conveys Australian views on legal and other matters directly to the CPA, and maintains regular contact with Australia's representative in the CPA Office of General Counsel.

quote.para: Australian Defence Force (ADF) personnel in Iraq are subject to Rules of Engagement which require compliance with applicable domestic and international law regarding their presence in Iraq. ADF members have received training in applicable law and Rules of Engagement as part of their force preparation prior to deployment. The Rules of Engagement are military orders enforced through the military chain of command. Other Australian officials in Iraq in an official capacity are issued with a booklet entitled “Operational Guidelines addressed to Australian Personnel Working in Post-Conflict Iraq”. The guidelines are designed to ensure that Australian personnel do not do anything that would violate Australia's international obligations, or that might attract criminal responsibility under Australia's Criminal Code.

answer.para: (3) Australia is not named as an Occupying Power in UN Security Council Resolution 1483 and thus does not bear the full burden of meeting the obligations of the Occupying Powers. Australia is, however, making a significant contribution to the efforts of a broad coalition of countries contributing to Iraq's rehabilitation, focusing our assistance in the field of agriculture. The assistance that Australia has provided to help meet these needs is summarised in Table A.

quote.para: Table A: Australian humanitarian and reconstruction assistance (detailed breakdown)

entry.para: Australian NGOs, including CARE Australia and Australian Red Cross
UNICEF - water, sanitation, health, child protection, nutrition
UN agencies responsible for coordinating humanitarian activities and logistical arrangements
CARE Australia - principally in the areas of water and sanitation and mine awareness programs
World Vision Australia - principally in the areas of water and sanitation and environmental health in primary schools
Save the Children Australia - support to eight paediatric hospitals across Iraq
Economic Policy, Water Supply and Sanitation

answer.para: (4) and (5) While emergency and reconstruction needs are progressively being identified and addressed by the Coalition, Iraqi counterparts and international organisations, rehabilitation efforts are being hampered by ongoing security concerns, including targeted sabotage of infrastructure by supporters of the former regime. Significantly degraded infrastructure and chronic problems will also take time to address. Needs assessments are being undertaken by the CPA, United Nations and International Financial Institutions, which will provide a comprehensive picture of requirements for further assistance. These assessments will be finalised for presentation at the donors' conference to be held in Madrid on 24 October 2003. Australia is maintaining an active dialogue on rehabilitation issues with CPA officials in Baghdad, and with the United States, the United Kingdom, UN agencies, and the International Financial Institutions.
(6) As explained in the answer to question one, Australia is not named as an Occupying Power in Iraq in UN Security Council Resolution 1483.
(7) See answer to question one.

(8) The CPA is the entity established to discharge the obligations of the Occupying Powers in Iraq and to enable the participation of other States in the interim administration and development of Iraq, as well as the provision of humanitarian and technical assistance. The status of the CPA is supported by UN Security Council Resolution 1483 and is consistent with international law relating to the roles and responsibilities of an Occupying Power.
(9) No. See also answer to question one.
(10) See organisation chart on the following internet site: http://www.cpa-iraq.org/CPAorgchart.pdf.

quote.para: (a) 14 Australian experts are currently seconded to the CPA. They are working in the following fields:
- Agriculture
- Economic policy
- Water and sanitation
- Trade
- Oil policy
- General Counsel
- Coalition coordination arrangements
- Baghdad and South Central Regions
(b) Australians are involved, inter alia, in:
- rehabilitating the agriculture sector and development of appropriate agriculture policy
- the 2003 and 2004 budget processes
- establishing a new salary structure for civil servants and implementing of salary payments to Iraqi civil servants
- water and sanitation issues, including the re-establishment of the responsible Ministry
- assisting the Ministry of Oil in dealing with a range of practical challenges in rehabilitating this sector
- working with the CPA Office of General Counsel on legal issues

- establishing the Council for International Coordination, which is the CPA's main mechanism for coordinating among contributing countries, and with UN and other agencies involved in Iraq's rehabilitation
helping to manage Baghdad and regional areas.

- The CPA has obligations under the Geneva Convention and Hague Regulations to ensure the security and humanitarian needs of the Iraqi people following the conflict. Australia has made a strong commitment to Iraq's rehabilitation. See also answers (a) and (b) above.

answer.para: (11) The Iraqi Governing Council was established on 13 July 2003. This is a significant step towards establishing a democratic Iraqi Government. The next stage will entail a process to develop a new constitution. The final stage will be the election of a sovereign Iraqi Government by the Iraqi people. The exact timeline for this process is a matter for the Iraqi Governing Council to determine.
Refer also to the answers to questions three and ten.
(12) and (13) The Government has not received such estimates of coalition or Iraqi fatalities.
(14) The Government does not have such information.

(15) See also the answer to question three. There are approximately 100 NGOs currently working in Iraq, a significant number of which are working in the health sector. The Government is not in a position to comment on the reliability of the assessments of all of these NGOs. However, AusAID is working with key UN agencies, including UNICEF and WHO, and the major international NGOs, namely CARE, International Committee of the Red Cross, Save the Children and World Vision which are implementing vital reconstruction activities in the health sector. AusAID has provided assistance to a number of these organisations to respond to health needs, as detailed in Attachment A.
(16) (17) and (18) It would be premature to answer these questions prior to Coalition investigators completing their search for WMD in Iraq, but see also answer to question 19.

(19) The Government is confident in the judgment that Iraq possessed a WMD capability in the lead-up to the war. Australian intelligence agencies are continuing to assess the scope and nature of that capability in the light of current investigations.
(20) and (21) No doubts were expressed by the intelligence agencies or my department about whether Iraq had WMD capability.
(22) This question should be directed to the Minister for Defence, whose department is co-ordinating the Australian contribution.

(23) It is not possible to compare the cost directly. The cost of UNMOVIC and IAEA weapons inspectors is paid out of the UN and IAEA budgets respectively. Australia pays an annual assessed contribution to both of these organisations.

(24) and (25) Australia believes that international organisations such as UNMOVIC and the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) have a role to play in Iraq. Australia has conveyed this view to the US and UK Governments.

quote.para: However, the circumstances under which these organisations operated before the conflict with Iraq commenced have changed. This has been recognised by the UN Security Council in UNSCR 1483 which “underlines the intention of the Council to revisit their mandates”.

The Australian Government favoured the early return of the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) to resume its safeguards responsibilities in Iraq in line with Iraq's Non-Proliferation Treaty safeguards agreement. Australia made its position known in Washington. An IAEA team was despatched to the Iraqi nuclear research centre al-Tuwaitha and commenced inspections on 7 June.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources, upon notice, on 11 August 2003:

question.para: (1) With respect to the implementation of the changes to the importation and conversion of low volume second hand motor vehicles introduced by the Motor Vehicle Standards Amendment Act 2001, can he advise whether a post implementation review of the new scheme been conducted; if so, by whom, what were its findings and is it publicly available; if a review has been conducted but not publicly released, why not.
(2) Has any assessment of the employment implications of the new arrangements been conducted; if not why not; if so, what are the findings.
(3) Has the new Act and arrangements achieved the Government's objectives; if so, what is the evidence to support that conclusion; if not, what are the inadequacies of the Act.

(4) Will the Government release the report produced by the Office of Small Business in 2000 on the employment impacts of the move to the Specialist and Enthusiast Vehicle Scheme (SEVS); if not, why not.

talker.name: Macfarlane, Ian, MP
Mr Ian Macfarlane
talker.role: Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) I understand you have asked a similar question (QON 2173) of the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, the Hon John Anderson MP. As he has portfolio responsibility for the Act, I refer this question to him.

(2) The Motor Vehicles Standards Amendment Act came into effect on 1 April 2002. Transitional arrangements allowed registered vehicle holders to continue modifying and plating permitted vehicles for the market until 7 May 2003. Given the short period of time the Act has been fully effective, there has been no assessment of the employment implications of the new arrangement.
(3) It is too early to determine how successful the Act has been in achieving the Government's objective given the short period of time it has been in effect.

(4) The Government will not be releasing the report. talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 11 August 2003 and it was transferred to the Minister for Transport and Regional Services:

quote.para: (1) What restrictions apply to the private importation to Australia by Australian citizens of second hand motor vehicles less than 15 years old and when were they introduced.
(2) Were the restrictions imposed as a result of any report or recommendation of a parliamentary committee.
(3) Were the restrictions imposed as part of the implementation of an announced Government policy.
(4) For what reasons was the ban imposed on privately imported second hand motor vehicles less than 15 years old.
(5) Will he allow the importation of vehicles purchased privately overseas before the restrictions were imposed.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Motor Vehicle Standards Regulations 1989 permit the private importation to Australia by Australian citizens of used motor vehicles less than 15 years old under the provisions of regulations 12 to 16 inclusive. In general terms, the regulations provide for:

quote.para: - personal imports, where the vehicle has been owned and used continuously for a qualifying period overseas;
- where the vehicle complied with the Australian Design Rules when it was first manufactured and delivered for use in transport; or

- where the vehicle is eligible under the Specialist and Enthusiast Vehicle Scheme and the vehicle model is included in the schedule of a registered automotive workshop, in which case the import application must be made by, and approval issued to, the registered automotive workshop.

answer.para: (3) Yes. Changes to the import provisions of the Motor Vehicle Standards Regulations 1989 were introduced as part of the Government's response to the Review of the Motor Vehicle Standards Act 1989. These changes were announced by Senator Minchin and me on 8 May 2000 and included:

quote.para: - abolition of the former low volume scheme for used vehicles after a two year transition period;
- creation of the Specialist and Enthusiast Vehicle Scheme;
- removal of provisions allowing the importation of vehicles for dismantling; and
- extension of the qualifying period for personal imports from 90 days to 12 months.
(4) There is no ban on privately imported second hand vehicles. There are restrictions, as noted in (1) above.
(5) Yes, if the vehicle can be imported under one of the provisions of the Motor Vehicle Standards Regulations as outlined in (1) above.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 11 August 2003:

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: Australia sponsored with the United States and New Zealand a counter terrorism workshop for Pacific Island countries in March 2002. Australia did not sponsor a workshop of this sort in March 2003. The 2002 workshop helped to raise awareness in Pacific Island countries of the nature of the threat of international terrorism and of the role Pacific Island countries have in combating this threat, including through compliance with mandatory United Nations Security Council (UNSC) resolutions and relevant international instruments. Workshop participants agreed that the focus of the regional effort should be on taking practical steps to address the terrorist problem, including the early completion by Pacific Island countries of the reporting requirements of UNSC Resolution 1373.

question.para: (1) Has the Minister seen the numerous recent media reports calling for the Australian Broadcasting Corporation to be allowed to raise advertising revenue to supplement its budget which have been supported by some members of the Government.
(2) Will the Minister unequivocally rule out making the policy change or any other policy change which would undermine the independence of the public broadcaster; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Yes.
(2) The Government remains committed to the independence of the ABC as provided for by Parliament under the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act 1983.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 18 August 2003:

quote.para: Further to the answer to part (3) of question No. 1944 (Hansard, 12 August 2003, page 18177), will he, for the life of this Parliament, rule out amending the Australian Broadcasting Act 1983 in a way which would allow the public broadcaster to raise revenue through commercial advertising on its television and radio networks; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: Yes.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 18 August 2003:

question.para: (1) Has the Minister seen the article by the Shadow Minister for Communications, titled “Ads would undermine our ABC” that appeared in The Age newspaper on 14 August 2003.
(2) Can he explain how the Government's policy differs from that expressed in the article.

(3) Is the Minister aware that the overwhelming majority of Australians who support the ABC do not want the public broadcaster to be competing for commercial advertising revenue with the commercial media moguls because of the threat to its independence and the ensuing consequences for Australian democracy.
(4) Will he make an immediate public statement to the effect that he will not allow the ABC to raise revenue through commercial advertising; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Yes.
(2) The Government has no plans to amend the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act 1983 to permit advertising on the television and radio services.
(3) The Minister has received no correspondence on this issue.
(4) See answer to part (2).
